Just stumbled across this video. That tab on the back of lawn mower blades was invented much later. Mower blades were just flat before the grass bag came into play and the clippings had to be lifted and blown into the bag. They also served a dual purpose of mulching by shutting of the exits but keeping the clippings airborne inside of the mower deck long enough to chop them over and over again. What cuts the grass depends on the sharpness and momentum of the mower blade and the weight of the grass blade. “Come on Man”

I saw a video years ago that talked about what LENGTH of the mower blade needed to be sharpened for the actual cutting of the grass.  The answer was, the OUTSIDE 2 inches as this did the majority of the slicing of the standing grass. The reasons for sharpening the rest of the length of the blade, were to aid in the chopping up of the grass AFTER it was cut off, AND to maintain blade speed by reducing blade friction against the air, moisture, and grass particles. I have mowed commercial and residential properties for sixteen years, so this video was extra interesting too me. Thanks for sharing.

The newer and faster commercial mowers make a better, cleaner cut than the older commercial mowers up through the late 1990s, and for the most part, still better than the current non-commercial mowers. I asked a mower retailer about this and he said the older mowers were limited by OSHA to 120 mph tip speed. The combination of faster tip speed creating greater impact and more up-lift should enhance the cleaner cut..

The rough pasture and brush cutting Bushogs I think also cut at a 120 mph tip speed. In general, though, a sharp blade is not preferred for cutting brush. A dulled blade, rather than cutting, will burst and fracture the stems or small trunks and slow further growth more than a clean cut.

dude needs to sharpen that blade.  Yes, the bend of the blade creates lift but beating the grass with a fast-moving blunt object is ripping the grass apart the way a speeding car rips apart... well... you get the idea.  Scythes mow by combining a sharp edge with swift motion not requiring 'lift'. Sharpen your mower and it will require less force and will make a cleaner cut on every stroke, you can mow much faster and have a cleaner, healthier lawn.  Same principle with all cutting implements, EVEN SCISSORS, use a sharper edge for a better cut that requires less force to complete, less energy per cut, less wear on the blade, which results in longer tool life.

You might want to look from the development of the tooling. They used scythes and where the big swing of it was not feasible sickles. The scythe is purely cutting be inertia of the grass (or what ever). If the grass is wet or too long such that it is bent, the attacking angle of the blade is suboptimal, preventing easy cutting or even cutting at all. If you use a sickle, you need to grab the top of the good to get cut, so the attack angle of the blade is proper and also rising the inertia of the good to cut (the movement of the sickle's blade is too slow the little inertia of the usual cutting good). The mower is an automated combination of the two, but only affecting the attack angle significantly (at least in my opinion). I do not believe the air flow is that strong, that the inertia of the grass is augmented more than a tiny touch.

Love your videos.  I am old enough to remember that in the early 1960s, rotary mowers had flat blades because they didn't have catchers.  In fact I flatten mine with a sledge hammer so there is less drag on the motor and less grass choking up the chute where the catcher isn't attached, and they still mow fine.  Furthermore whippersnippers use just inertial cutting.   So I don't think the suction thing is that important.  Maybe it gives a cleaner cut at lower speeds??  But those old mowers with flat blades cut just fine.

You are completely wrong when saying that lawnmowers do not cut grass like scissors would.  There are some lawnmowers that DO WORK THAT WAY.  They are "Reel" mowers, some are hand push, some are powered.  They have a tubular form where a set of revolving blades are set in the periphery of a tube and the grass is cut when the grass blades get caught between the edge of a turning blade and a static blade.  Very simple, and best suited to fine grass lawns that are not very long.  The blades need to be kept quite sharp so they can cut the grass, unlike rotary mowers which effectively tear the grass blades.

The video should also teach you why having a sharp blade(s) will dramatically improve everything about your mower's cutting efficiency.  Buy a second set of blades and change them out frequently.  Refresh the edge for the next change time.  Your mower will use less fuel, your grass will look a lot better, and your deck will not collect nearly as much debris to be cleaned out later.  Sharp blades cut the grass instead of beating it up.  Just look at the grass blades closely and you will see the difference.  You can do a demonstration by installing your blades backwards and try to cut the grass with the dull side of the blade.  The grass blade edges will look torn instead of a clean cut.  Doesn't work very well and requires a huge difference in horsepower.  Good luck!

So you know there are different types of blades. The blade fin adjust for the type of lawn you have and the amount of dirt or sand that is there. So if you have little grass and a lot of dirt you get a flatter blade so you get less dust bowls in the neighbor hood. The other thing is that on a blade only the first inch cut the lawn while you are moving usually that’s why the front or edges of the blade wear out first. The angle you grind on the blade also matters. Hope this helps for future videos.

Twelve years ago I bought a replacement lawn mower blade that was supposedly optimized for "mulching". Behind the regular blade edge with the upward tab, there was a notch, then a second blade mounted higher and angled downward. When I installed it, I noticed two things immediately: 1) the mower was significantly quieter; and 2) cut quality was exceedingly poor.

That's when I learned about the vacuum created by a mower blade - which was cancelled out on this blade by the extra downward-facing cutting edge. The aerodynamic changes related to the lack of vacuum were also apparently responsible for the reduction in noise. I took the blade back for a refund and have used standard blades ever since.

Another fun fact: The tab on the rear of the blade can eventually wear down from friction against the grass clippings it's pushing upward. I've gone through two heavily used blades that, in addition to having a lot of material worn off the front from repeated sharpenings, had the rear tabs (which gently curved upward) worn down to a knife-edge.

This video illustrates the reason for a sharp well designed blade. As well the need for a well designed deck. I have had a number of lawn mowers over the decades. My 15 year old Ariens has the best suction, pick and even cut.
A reel mower cuts grass using opposing blades

Scythe, brushcutters, hovering lawnmowers, trimmers... all cut grass pretty well without creating an upward draft. And that's because of inertia: at the speed the blade hits, the force required to push grass out of the way is bigger than cutting force so it cuts through.


That same effect is at play in lawnmowers and not mentionning it is, at least, an editorial mistake.


In fact, the fanning action of the blade has the role of moving the cut grass around and into the collector bag (or throwing it away to the side). And as far as I know, it may be it's main or even sole purpose.


My bet is that the upward draft is far from straight up at the individual grass blade level because it would be very turbulent, and that it's magnitude is anyhow pretty small.

Huntsville Landscaper here:

Look at String Trimmers.
Commonly known as a weed eater, this versatile tool utilizes helicopter-rotor-like physics to do anything from obliterate weeds to fine tune edges.
Note the gyroscopic effect the spinning head has, resisting tilt and providing steadiness. Most notably with a dual string head.
Note that (for a Counterclockwise spinning head) the left side provides a finer cut with the string "bouncing" off the grass. The right side provides a coarse cut that digs into the grass.
Heavier string makes a huge difference in performance as well. And IS THERE A DIFFERENCE IN THE SHAPE??? There's so so many types of string: round, square, hex, and various twists and plastic hardness.

Oh, and the direction you swing from in addition to the angle of the head all makes a difference.

AND ANOTHER IMPORTANT THING: can you PROVE that the guard actually helps??? I know it sounds preposterous to even ask, but too many "professional" landscapers take them off.

Yup, the wings create the suction and pull the grass up. Some decks cut better than others depending on how good they move air. Then you got High lift, Med lift, and Low lift blades. High Lifts create the most suction and pulls the grass tight, which gives a smooth cut and nice stripes. That’s why most lawn care guys, like myself, like the high lifts.

Love your videos, but you are wrong.  When the tabs are worn off the  grass still gets cut, but is not thrown into the grassbox properly. I know,  I have replaced blades. The blades of grass have inertia (very little), but the speed of the blade is very fast, allowing the cut. Similar to a samurai cutting a banana or someting. There is a general airflow to the grassbox  caused by the propellor effect of the tabs  + the tabs will  physically throw grass  to the grassbox, but the main cutting action is as per samurai method. Regarding tree leafs on the grass I think the action is as follows: If the tree leaf is below the blade the blade moves over it, the tab sucks it up and the tab on the next blade tries to throw it in the grass box.

If you have ever operated a cylinder lawn mower, hand operated or powered, you have operated a lawn mower that cuts grass blades by cutting them against a bar instead of in the way that the mowers in this video cut grass. YES! You read it right! There IS a lawnmower that operates using shear force, like scissors do. I've operated the push mower in my younger years once, a very very long time ago, and it is a lot of effort to get those blades cutting the grass! In the case of the push cylinder mower design, the effort to make the blade spin is supplied by the operator pushing the wheels of the mower forward and making them turn using a gear ratio that made the blades spin faster than the wheels themselves turned. Powered versions simply use an engine to supply both force to spin the blade and move the wheels.

Some lawn mowers cut like scissors.   Think of a push mower or a golf course greens mower.   There are 2 opposing blades.  There is a fixed bar and a moving blade that cuts along the bar.

The reel type mowers do use an opposing piece of metal and actually cuts the grass. Check out Golf Courses that's what they use on the greens.

The more common lawn mowers don't actually cut the grass so much as they rip the upper shaft off.

Compare the way the a lawn looks when side by side areas one cut with a reel type mower vs the centrifugall type mower.
The everyday type push mower leaves a swirl pattern and the blades of grass have jagged edges where a reel type uses the reel to push the blades up against the cutting bar like the jaws of scissors.

OK, so I have a Snapper zero turn. It cuts horribly. It blows the grass down. It will only cut on the discharge side. The other side does not cut. One weird thing about the deck is the edge is rolled in, rather than out or straight down like most decks. I have fought this lawn mower for 15 years. I've tried speeding the blade up which helped, but still half the grass is not cut. I've also tried increasing the lift. I welded more metal on the lift tabs. This also made a minor improvement, but still cuts poorly. I have finally drilled holes on the non-discharge side which helps even more, but still is not right. It seems there is just way too much turbulence and the grass does not lift. The other unusual thing about it is that it is a single 28 inch blade. I don't know if that is the issue or why this thing won't mow.

I will say I will never buy a Snapper.

One of the main contributors to split grass blades is a dull mower blade. Lawn mowers typically have multiple blades that spin rapidly. If even one blade is not sharpened correctly, your grass blades are torn, rather than cut cleanly across the top. A split down a grass blade invites disease into the lawn and may make the grass look yellow or wilted.

missing a HUGE part of the whole process, while there is suction, the suction on the grass is actually very small, it more offsets the blades pushing the grass away by its velocity that would typically push air away from itself. the actual suction is barely enough to move cut ends of the grass to move it towards the bag chute. if you go back 60-70 years ago those push mowers didnt use airflow to pull up on the grass. its more about velocity of the blades verses acceleration limits of the grass. if you take lets say a sword and push it against a sapling all it does is make it bend the sapling. if you go a little faster it might dig in a little, but if you swing it really fast it will cut through it cause the sapling will not have time to accelerate in the direction of the sword's impact. you can also see this work if you have a machete (there is zero "suction") find some tall grass and move the blade through the grass, it might catch a few pieces and sheer it if the blade is super sharp, but it will lay the grass over. now swing faster and the grass again... can not accelerate as fast as the blade is going in short enough time, thereby cutting the grass. ALSO, the amount of energy on the fine edge can not be dispersed quick enough through more of the grass blade. hence why a sharper blade cuts grass easier as opposed to a duller one. a dull blades impact point is broader thus dispersing the energy in a larger area area.


so key to actually cutting grass is sharpest edge, and highest speed. the whole "suction" or "vacuum" thing has so little of effect that its more of a old wives tail. but I guess thats what you get for asking your barber about physics.

FYI, old reel-type mowers operate more like a scissors. Curved blades on the reel sheer against the cutter bar to produce the linear stress. The blades have to be set up just right to the cutter bar, and the cutter bar has to be rotated when it starts to round off from wear.

The lift on the blades serves 2 purposes actually.  It generates the lift to cut the grass and also ejects the cut grass out out of the discharge.  If you look at a mulching blade the lift portion of the blade likely looks like a shark tooth which serves to chop the pieces of cut grass into smaller pieces of cut grass.

Basically, rotary mowers don't cut the grass - they tear it. How neatly they tear it depends on how sharp the blades are, and the blades are rarely sharp.

By using a different kind of camera you can compare a rotary mower with a reel type mower. Look at the ends of the grass under high magnification after being cut with a reel type lower versus a rotary mower and you'll see a significant difference.

Those "tabs" (or flaps) are primarily for transporting the cut grass away from the cutting blade. It's very similar to an airplane wing.
The effect of low pressure "sucking" the grass blades straight is more or less the cherry on top, but it is not how the lawn mower does it's work.


The most important factor of lawn mowing is the sharpness of the cutting blade.
A dull blade will just rip the grass and/or not cut it at all.
Inertia is a very significant factor in this.
With a dull blade you require a much higher rotational speed of the mower to have the same cutting effect as with the sharp blade.


Additionally you need the flaps bent at a slight angle to create pressure differential to transport the cut grass away from the blade. Most often into a grass bin (catcher).
Without those you make just a grass smoothie.

I don't think this is correct. I think it's just the speed and shape of the tip of the blade, as well as the height of the grass in relation to the blade. The natural elasticity of the grass is what causes it to spring back up. The mass of the grass on top of the blade is enough to prevent the grass from being pulled around the blade. With a sharp blade (unlike the one in the video) this creates a small stress point that overcomes the tensile strength of the grass, and severs it. with a dull blade, that stress point is much larger and is spread over a longer length of grass. Similar to ep. 194 with the bullet through the playing card; the card didn't need any suction to prevent it from being pushed over. The speed alone is enough.
The bent part is just for ejecting the clippings. There are flat blades that cut just as well as the ones with the bend.

I learned all about mower decks in 2008 when I purchased a Hustler Super Z. I had to clean the deck 1/2 through mowing my 4 1/2 acres,because it would clog up and start throwing softball side clods out. After much research and (absolutely NO help from Hustler) I figured out the theory/concept of a mower deckand blades. The blades work in conjunction with the deck to do 2 things  1: to create lift and 2: to move it OUT. Both things have to happen or you get a nice cut ( suction) for a short time because the cut grass just gets packed to the deck, this does 2things. 1: the grass is now packing up on top of all the cut grass 2: completely redesigning the shape of the deck which destroys the airflow. After 2 years of relentless effort,I finally found someone at Hustler that confessed that the XR-7 deck is a bad design and for $1000.00 + 300.00 shipping I could buy a new style deck. I sharpen my lawn mower blade EVERY TIME that I mow. I use a silicon carbide sharpening stone. There are 3 important "gotchas" to be sure of.
1. Soak silicon carbide stone in water first to keep stone cool.
2. Repeatedly spray cutting surface with dilute detergent as cutting lubricant.
3. Wipe cutting surface frequently with wet paper towel to remove metal particles that would otherwise block the tiny cutting edges.


The difference in results is remarkable. Lawn is flat, not bent.

I am pretty sure everyone is over-thinking this. If you have ever used really beat-up blades that have long lost those wing things on them, you will notice that the grass doesn't discharge out the chute well at all but still cut just fine but tend to plug up. That is their purpose. They are particularly important if you have a bagger. When you push the cut blades of grass, you are also pushing air and the inertia of the cut grass is just going to happen to pull air along with it. A lawn mower blade literally bushwhacks its way through.

As far as the airflow lift that it supposedly creates, in a mulching mower with no discharge chute, the air has nowhere to go, thus it can't really create any upward lifting airflow. And with all the standing grass, I would expect that it would act as an airflow attenuator. And weed whippers don't utilize any such airflow inducing device and they cut grass pretty well, too.

When you cut the front part of the mower frame off, you eliminated some of the vacuum effect it uses.  Like a fan blower housing increases in distance from the fan before it exits creating blown air, the mower uses the rounded portion of he frame (most are closer just past the exit port and rise as the blade goes around to the exit port.  This also serves as a duct to eject the grass either to the side or the rear depending on the design.  Pressure above the blade is higher due to the air foil behind the blade and lower under the blade.  Air is pulled in around the bottom of the frame and ejected out with the grass at the ejection port.

​ In the late 70s I had a friend that designed mower decks. At the time I was working on a JD deck that had these radical L shape mower blades just under 80 degrees  I remember asking him why they would design them like that. He referred me to someone else that could explain it better but explained why they built them like that. He showed me deck design drawings that showed how they work.  On riding mowers the bags are mounted on the back . The grass side discharged  but threw a tunnel upwards to the bags. The best way of getting the grass to travel all the way into the bag was the high lift blades .  Any way just search best blades for bagging lawn mowers. or the difference between mulching blades and bagging blades . 2 way blades/3 way blades. or just go to sites that sell blades" Sears "  They show the difference. Bagging high lift. Also the blades pull the air from under the deck .The high lift blades are like a fan blowing out the discharge. This is also the reason there are kits that can be added to a deck for mulching .(Using less curved blades) . They limit the amount of air flow keeping most of the cut grass in the deck cutting it more than once as it circulates out the bottom. Sorry about the rant .Hope this helps you.

Most of the cutting occurs at the perimeter of the blades. They are pumping air from under the deck out the discharge chute, and replacement air is rushing in under the perimeter of the deck. This airflow lifts the grass near the perimeter of the deck for cutting. If the blade is turning 3000 RPM, that is 6000 blade tips per minute, or 100 blade tips per second. A lawn mower does not advance very far in 1/100 of a second (about 3/10 of an inch at 6 MPH) so the only new grass that needs to be cut is near the perimeter of the blade/deck.

This is wrong. The turn-up on a mower blade is to discharge the grass, not lift it. Before rotary mowers were invented, a common way to cut grass was with a scythe, or a sickle. These were sharp curved blades on a handle which were swept through the grass to cut it. They had no turn-up on the blades at all. The first rotary mowers also had no turn-up on the blades as the blades were exposed beneath the mower and did not need to discharge the grass. The turn-ups were only introduced when it became necessary to discharge the grass into a collector (grass catcher or bag) or discharge it out of the side of the mower when the blades became enclosed (for safety reasons). I still have a blade disc from one of these early mowers and the blades are completely flat. The blades cut the grass due to the inertia of the grass stems - the blades cut them before they have time to bend over.

So... Slight issue with your "blade causing updraught" theory. I'm not sure if they're common in the states but in the UK and Europe it's quite common to use a hover mower which works like a hovercraft by sucking air in from above and pushing it into the cutting area to make the mower body float on a cushion of air. They typically use straight blades but some do use curved ones like shown in the video.
I've worked as a gardener for about 7 years now and cutting grass is almost a daily task, the main thing that defines how well the grass will cut is how long it is. It wants to stand up by itself (the bottom of the shoot is fairly rigid) but if it's too long it flops over, if it's too long to fit under the mower then it won't cut well and you're better off hitting it with a strimmer/weedwhacker first then raking the long cut grass off to expose the shoots. It's all down to inertia really, blade sharpness counts for something but mostly it's down to how fast it swings

I feel like you missed the mechanics of how inertia works.
If you thwack the blade at the top, it deflects and doesn't get cut. But if you thwack it lower down, the inertia of the top part can't be overcome by the shear strength of the impact point. And it gets cut. The lift force def helps more blades end up past that point, but is only half the story.

So, we kinda got this one right. The tabs are infact to create airflow, but not necessarily to lift the grass up to be cut. A sharp cutting edge, and sheer speed of the blade tip against the rigidity of the plant is what cuts the grass. The airflow created by the tabs is important to help discharge the grass and keep the cutting area from "plugging" up with spent clippings. Now, fun fact, mulching blades have a higher tab on the back to help facilitate better airflow to keep the clippings circulating in and out of the cutting zone till they are ground up to the point their mass is so small that they drop back into your yard. This is also why its  imperative for a good cut, to scrape your mower deck several times a year. Grass buildup changes the airflow, and won't allow for proper mulching.

You maybe mistaken about the tab on the back of the Mower blade. It does help provide a partial vacuum. That partial vacuum is for waste management it's to help the grass blow out from under the mower for discharge. This Discharge prevents cut grass blades from falling on the top of uncut grass blades or cutting the grass blades twice (extra work). But it's the previous lawn mower blade (the other half of the lawnmower blade) that provides a partial vacuum which may straighten up the Grass blade. The biggest thing that makes the grass blade raise up is the sun. This grass has been growing toward the sun. And growing grass does not lay down. It has developed vertical strength and inertia. Whereas the shearing action of the stable stationary grass blade against the fast rotating mower blade will cut it. The taps on the blade help keep a high-pressure area above the blade and juggle the clippings until it can sling them outside the discharge hole(a low pressure area).

consider the lift on an airplane wing. the upper section forces air to move over more surface before getting to the other side. this makes the air move faster and creates lower air pressure. the lower air pressure gives the plane lift. the air over the tab does the same thing causing a vacuum effect on the blades. the reason it can do ok without the tab is the stiffness of the grass at a natural state, but if you run the mower over pure sand both with and without tab, you will see a difference.

I've been in the outdoor power equipment industry for over 20 years and have used many mowers and seen many mower blades, Here is exactly how a lawn mower blade works. A lawn mower blade has a air lift on the back of it also called a trailing edge or tip, that trailing edge does alot of things, it creates an upward air draft or a vacuum, suction to lift or stand the grass up so that it gets cut evenly and it also creates that upward air draft (vacuum or suction) to lift and eject the cut clippings and debris out the side of the deck if side discharging or up into a rear bagger unit if bagging. Now there are many different types of mower blades, the blades shown in this video were standard hi-lift blades, that only are good for cutting and throwing the grass clippings out the side of the deck or up into a rear bagger unit, the other type of mower blade is a mulching blade, which is a funny looking wavy blade that has alot of flat and raised areas on the top surface, a mulching blade also has a trailing edge to create an upwards air draft to lift,cut and when mulching throw the clippings upwards (towards the top of the deck's underside) then the blade also creates a downdraft air flow or downdraft pressure that sucks the clippings back into the blade to be cut repeatedly, then there are gator blades that have a serrated trailing edge, the serrated teeth do not cut the grass, those are the air lifts (trailing edge) the teeth are bent to where they are directed towards the center of the mower deck where they redirect the air flow that pushes the clippings up and down back over the cutting edge to be cut into tiny tiny particles. I hope this information clarifies some things on how a lawn mower blade cuts the grass, one other thing to mention, a lawn mower blade regardless of what type it is - it is a lawn mower blade and all lawn mowers blades have one thing in common - they all cut the grass.

No.
The blade is able to cut the grass for the same reason a bullet will go through a blade of grass, but if you take a bullet between your fingers and try to push it through, the grass will just bend away.
More specifically, to make the whole leaf bend away, the force introduced to the grass must cause some acceleration in the first phase, and this is governed by the classic equation F=ma.
The faster the cutting edge moves, the faster the blade of grass has to dodge, and hence the faster it has to accelerate, and the higher the force required to do so is.
At some point the force exerted on the blade of grass is large enough that is overcomes what can be thought of as it's tensile strength, though really it's a complex combination of shear stresses and tensile strengths of the fiber structure.
The same phenomenon can be observed this way: Take a raw dry spaghetti between your fingers and wave it up and down. This is easy when done slowly, but wave too fast and the spaghetti will break. You can balance one on top of your extended palm, but you can also drop the spaghetti and cut it in half midair with a karate-slash if you're fast enough.

As a dude who has mowed lawns for a living we'd use our knowledge of suction (w/ our 52-inch mower) to determine the deck height when cutting certain types of grasses. For instance, a turf type Fescue can be mowed quite short (season, climate and general thickness dependent), however Zenith Soysia shouldn't be mowed less than 1.5 inches. On average for a homeowner, most grasses shouldn't be mowed below 2 inches. Thanks for making a video on this, it's appreciated.

I think I got it? similar to the helicopter there designing to put on mars with two blades it compresses the air in between to give it more lift. They need to do this because of the low pressure on Mars. The same way, one of those toy helicopters work with a weaker motor and are still able to fly. Anyway, the lawnmower as it spins with its upward bent bar on the blade is increasing the pressure at the top of the compartment of the lawnmower and the higher the pressure the slower an object can travel through that space. This increase in pressure at the top slows the motion of the grass holding it in place allowing the blade to easily cut the grass.

Yes my thoughts too on the reel mower , very similar to the scissors cutting/shearing action which allows that super close cutting action on the golf course. Naturally keeping a sharp edge is critical with whatever tool you are cutting with. On my standard bladed mowers I barely touch the blade with a fine grinder stone first touching the top just enough to turn the burr edge down or even not quite to a burr then just a touch from the bottom until I get a sharp burr back to the top which I leave alone not honeing as with a delicate razor/knife edge. This leaves the burr to cut the wrapped around grass blade which has been working well but as I see your high speed action I’m thinking about gently turning the wire edge to neutral as with a standard cutting tool as there is less wrapping/friction action than just straight cutting unless of course the blade is getting dull in which case it’s back to ripping/dragging  action.

I have a "lawn tools" video suggestion: I am sure you are familiar with weed whacker type tools that use a plastic "string" to cut various types of vegetation. The default string is typically just a long piece of flexible plastic with a circular cross section. But, you can also find premium kinds of string for these devices. I have seen square and triangular string that claims the sharp edges cut better. At the same time though, I am also aware that thinner edges are very likely to wear and break faster, because they are thinner. I have also seen some other more exotic types of string for these devices. I would love to see a video using a high speed camera to compare the capabilities of several different options and, if it is not too difficult, to estimate the strengths and weaknesses of each (for example, I suspect the triangular string would be more likely to break against wood and other harder targets than the round).

Destin - nice as always to see an analytic eye turned to everyday stuff. And I will agree that there are a lot of factors at play in a mower, and fine to speculate in an informed way. But all that said, some commenters here have pointed out some factors you skipped over - such as grass blade inertia (no need to go to "moment of inertia...") - and one you (of all people!) seem to have missed - air viscosity - that are at play. Without measures or at least an approximate quantitative assessment, hard to be sure where the "meat" of the cut process is, but I suspect most of the cutting happens because of fast-moving cutting blades hitting grass blades that cannot move out of the way of the sharp edge due to inertia and air resistance, before their shear limit is exceeded and the blade is "cut." - exacty the inertial cut you dismissed in your paper demo. Air moving in the housing due to the blade lips is into the housing around the outer edges (thus blowing the blades horizontal centripetally near the outer edge), then in a circular manner around and above the cutting blade (thus tending to lay the blades down in a circular pattern), then out of the housing through the shute. I can't imagine there is very much lifting of the blades upward the way you describe, as that would really require pulling air out of the ground... :)

Dear Destin: Since your topic above has something to do with blades, there is an analogy to an airplane wing. I've been trying to find the answer to the following question for years, but I keep getting the same reply from people in the know. But I don't believe it. Maybe you can help.
Since you have a degree in aeronautical engineering, you should be able to explain the question. The question is this:
When a simple airplane is in a constant altitude turn of a random angle of bank of say 60 degrees relative to the natural horizon, is the outer wing flying faster than the inner wing or are both wingtips flying at the same airspeed?
I maintain they are both flying at the same airspeed, but most of the pilots I know say the outer wing is flying faster because it has a greater arc to turn in the same amount of time as the inner wing. I would agree with this if we were talking about a helicopter blade when comparing the speed of the inner part near the hub as to the wingtip. But in an airplane that's turning, the wings are not connected to the ground. Think of the wings as one long wing.
I believe when the wing is turning in a level altitude it doesn't "know" the difference whether it's level or doing a loop. The earth just happens to be a nearby object that our eyes use for comparison.
Of course, the earth provides an atmosphere for there to be life, but you can also hypothesize a similar situation in outer space where there is an atmosphere. What do you say? Are both wingtips flying at the same airspeed or not? Thanks in advance.

Great video. The conclusion is a bit wrong though. The barber's theory reminds me of the Suck-cut from Wayne's World :) A blade of grass has it's own moment of inertia. This simply means that it wants to resist being accelerated because it has length and a mass. That's why in the video the grass can be seen bending over the blade as its struck. You can feel the inertia effect by skimming the grass with your finger tips. The faster you hit it, the harder it feels. At 200mph the grass would seem pretty solid to the blade enabling it to shear. He actually demonstrated the effect perfectly at the beginning using the paper and blade. The tab on the blade is primarily there as a fan to turn the mower into a vacuum cleaner thus removing the grass cuttings, although it would also help to make the grass stand up to achieve a more uniform cut.

A little disappointed that you missed a HUGE opportunity to talk about the first law of motion.

An object at rest wants to stay at rest. The grass wants to stand up naturally. A single grass blade has very little inertia, that is why it is easy to bend. However if the mower blade is moving at high speed the grass’ inertia is enough to overcome the force of the blade contacting it and it shears.

While “lift” does play a role here, it is marginal. Look at some of the electric mowers on the market that have zero lift on the blades. These blades cut because they move the blade fast enough that the grass’ inertia prevents it from bending out of the way and it shears instead.

If you want to get deeper, in addition to grass’ low inertia, it is also not very dense nor aerodynamic so the grass also has atmosphere that helps the shearing action. Like when you were whacking the paper with the blade. Paper is flimsy and light and will bend out of the way, BUT with enough speed the papers inertia as well as atmosphere will help it resist folding out of the way and it will shear instead.

I agree with the shape of the blade and underside of the deck theory, when it comes to 'Rotary Mowers'.  As you know however, the underside of the deck gets a very thick coating of cuttings that compress over time and impedes the 'air flow' efficiency of the mower.  I use a high vac "Mulching Blade" on my mower AND I clean/hose off the underside of the deck after each mowing.  Also, one viewer mentioned velocity, this too is very important.  Example, when you use a weedeater, it must run at high RPM to effectively cut the grass/weeds, if used at a low RPM, it's useless.  Also, if you use a Reel type mower, it shears the grass like scissors, which is not as traumatic on the grass and encourages new growth, according to the instructor in my Horticulture Class.

Overthinking as usual... Mower blades are smaller versions of scythes, the use of a scythe is traditionally called "mowing", which cut in a very similar method to the way a sword cuts.  The bend is to create suction in the mower so it itself wouldn't lift, like a helicopter, from the high rate of rotation and also aid in blowing out cut grass via the discharge.  It has nothing to do sucking up grass straight up, as the barber incorrectly theorized, as the scythe has no such mechanism.  Secondly, your barber is using clippers with a vacuum attachment that no one uses.  Thirdly, clippers use a scissor to cut, nothing like a mower or scythe blade.

you actually have opposing blade cutters, it was the first "mass mowing" technique; its the cutter bar mower, a large arrangement of small opposing blades next to each other like tiny scissors. Stil in production today due to the very light Horsepower/meter span. And pretty simple gearing, although maintenance heavy thats why the other mowing systems won eventualy. On the plus side, it can handle very heavy grass which your normal mower won't take as it clogs up/jams.

All the airflow does is move the grass away from the blade into the chute or collector. The cutting power comes from the torque of the blade. As the blade spins at 3000rpm it applies a lot of force over a very short period of time. Square strimmer line is blunt at low rpm with small diameter line it cuts with poor finish & efficiency. At high rpm with a higher diameter line it cuts very efficiently with clean finish. Obviously the strimmer bogs down if line is out too far you go beyond the sweet spot.

I believe that the lift on the back of the blades is not intended to straighten the grass up but to shoot it out the lawnmower, that's the reason why it is at the end of the blade and not in the rest of the blade. If this logic you explained was the correct one then why not have a longer lift on the blade to create more suction. I understand it could create more resistance to the blade if you do so. But It would not affect the cut as much. Also, you could have tested to proof you hypothesis by cutting off the lifts at the end of the blades and notice the change. Will it still cut the grass? I believe so. But my hypothesis is that when you go for tall grass it will slow down and maybe stop because it is not capable of shooting out the grass so it will accumulate and possibly stop the engine. Another thing is that if the lifts on the blades were distributed evenly on the blade. The grass closer to the point of rotation could get shot up to the ceiling of the mower creating hard compacted grass and eventually creating problems and giving you more maintenance because now you have to scrape it off.   😁👍

I'm fairly certain your barber didn't know what he was talking about. Air flow is going to be intrinsic to what is basically a sharpened fan regardless of the tabs on the blade. It seems far more likely that the tabs are there for waste removal (possibly to also reduce build up on the top of the housing?) and less about air flow. Also the vacuum on his hair clippers does not force the hair to stand up, that doesn't even make sense. The vacuum is located behind the clippers to catch most of the cut hair after its been cut, not before.

Dustin, plastic string type trimmers have no lip or airfoil, yet they cut just fine. The more I think about this, I gravitate toward the idea that the lip on the blade is indeed there to create air movement, but not for the reason to straighten the blades. I grew up in central Indiana, so there was no effing way I wasn't going to be mowing grass on Saturday. Shoveling snow in the winter, raking leaves in the fall, you know the drill. That is just the Rite Of Passage growing up in the mid-west.

Dustin, another great vid. Thanks. Like you - I've studied aeronautics (engineering), and didn't realise what that tab was for. I thought it was for throwing the cut blades of grass into the collection box.

That said - your vid has also explained to me why my neighbour has rejected some new 'improved' lawn mowers for his business, that he told me about a few years ago.. He is a Golf Course manager, looking after everything from paths, drainage and irrigation to the fairways and greens. He told me that the manufacturer had added more blades to a barrel or cylinder type cutter, and would give a better cut for his greens. He described the sales pitch like a well known gents razor, with added blades equalling a better cut. When he tried out the new cutters - they weren't working as well as they as advertised. The manufacturer didn't believe him initially. They had invested in computer simulations and the like, he said. After further tests - it was shown that the added blade was actually causing the grass to flatten slightly- resulting in a bad cut. I think he said there was an increase in pressure. This wasn't accounted for by the manufacturer. Not good, when in summer he is measuring the cut in fractions of a millimetre, everyday. Roughly 0.3mm is equal to just under 12 thousandths of an inch. So now his equipment is all back to the previous cutter. More is not necessarily a good thing.

I know your vid shows a rotary blade cutter, and barrel/cylinder type cutters have a bar to cut against - like your scissors, but the aerodynamics you talked about came to mind.

Watching your vid at approx 7:47, you can see why manufacturers go for a two bladed design.

1. for simplicity of manufacturing and cost.
2. A tri-blade design probably wouldn't work, because the grass blades wouldn't have time to be lifted into the correct position for the next blade to cut.

sickle mowers and old fashioned reel mowers both use opposing parts to shear similar to scissors. now the scythe and hand sickle both rely on Newton's laws of motion, specifically things at rest tend to stay at rest. The gas powered lawnmower also relies on this law except prior to the preferred resting position of the grass, the lift function of the blade repositions the blades of grass. physics is phun phor phred!!! Many people also do not understand that scissors nor lawn mower blades should be sharpened like a knife edge because it is shearing force that is being utilized, not slicing action. So properly sharpened lawnmower blades will have a cutting edge closer to 90 degrees than 180. I think 60 is optimal.

Rotary blade mowers are much cheaper than reel mowers and require less maintenance. However, they make a rougher cut on each individual blade of grass. This problem can be reduced by sharpening the blades regularly. Also note the cut varies depending on the position of the blade when it strikes the grass. When the blade is moving forward in relation to the direction the mower is traveling, it is moving faster than the tip on the opposite side in relation to stationary blades of grass; blade tip speed plus forward motion as opposed to blade tip speed minus forward motion. If you mow a section of grass moving forward and then re-mow the same section moving backward, you will find a flatter smoother cut because of the blade tips speed change in relation to the stationary grass when changing from forward to reverse mowing directions. The faster you travel while mowing the more pronounced this effect will be. A mower with two blades one behind the other and turning in opposite directions would produce a smoother flatter cut. However such a mower would be more expensive and ungainly. We use rotary mowers because they are less expensive and produce a barely acceptable cut. If you want a really smooth cut, use a push type reel mower. You will find it quite energy efficient (It uses your energy so no workouts at the gym are required). They are surprisingly easy to push! It won't cut thick stems so you will have to keep your lawn free of twigs. Additionally,  it will require special sharpening and adjustment. You can do this yourself but it takes a bit of study' and practice, even if you are mechanically inclined. Therefore, you can see why rotary mowers are used in the vast majority of cases. Want to see reel mowers in action? Go to a good golf course and you will see multiple reel mowers pulled in gangs behind a tractor. Another option is to fence your lawn and raise sheep. That's how to grass was kept short around old English country manors. The cut won't be very smooth but you can get your lawn mowed without equipment and you can watch the work in progress while sipping a cold one. Caution, there is other work involved in keeping sheep but your sheperd can take care of that. LOL

Have you looked at the physics of a Flymo? Where a standard rotary mower pulls air in from the bottom edge to stand up the grass and eject into the grass box, a flymo pulls air in through the motor on top. Most of the airflow is directed to one corner where the intake for the grass box is. The body of the mower acts as a hovercraft skirt, with excess high pressure from inside creating the lift. The grass box sits on top of the motor, and is used as a filter for the air returning through the motor.
You can tell when you need to empty the grass box as the airflow is reduced by the grass. This reduces the overpressure underneath and the mower becomes harder to move.

Not convinced by the vacuum theory, the main reason is because in the UK at least you can get hover mowers (flymo is the main brand) which do the opposite of creating a vacuum, the blades act as a downward facing fan so the mower has no wheels and floats like a hovercraft - it's designed for uneven ground. Strikers, which are just a bit of thin plastic cord spinning, also have no way of producing a vacuum, to have a vacuum you need an air outlet at the top for air to be pushed into so its no longer in the chamber, whilst some mowers do have this in their grass collection method, strimmers certainly don't.
The reason the grass cuts is simply the speed of the blade, although there's no pressure on the top of the blade there is so much inertia in the blade the grass simply can't bend out of the way fast enough - he actually demonstrated this principle with the paper and discarded it as an inertia cut!

How does a cylinder blade work?

It is also the inertial tear, the standing grass blade collides with the rotating blade at high speed, so fast enough that the self inertia of the grass blades is high enough to create the tension required for the rotating blade to cause the cut. think about the scissors as one side being the cutting blade and the other side being the inertia of the grass stem, and the grass being the paper sheet.

The blade also make sure that the grass stands strait up when meeting the cutting edge, through the wind tunnel, it is important the grass blades don't have a greater tendency to bend over away in the direction of the cutting, this way the inertia will not be sufficient and grass will escape the tension required for the tear.

Great video, as always. A few observations: 1) In the old days before mowers were powered by gas (or electric) motors, there were 'reel mowers' that actually did cut like scissors. There was a stationary 'blade' across the front of the mower. The wheels on the mower were connected to an open drum like mechanism with a set of rotating oblique blades that pressed up against and moved across the stationary blade in front - effectively cutting the grass much like scissors. 2) I suspect in modern mowers the tab on the blade is more about airflow to get clippings to move out the discharge shoot rather than to create lift to cut the blade. Although, mulching blades do have a larger tab to create more lift and more circulation in the cutting chamber. 3) The cutting action is improved with a sharper blade in two ways - motor efficiency and cleaner cutting action. If the blade is dull there is more resistance to blade rotation and the engine has to work harder. You may have heard your engine get bogged down in tall grass? It will do the same thing even in a lawn that is not overly tall if the blade is not sharp.  The second benefit of a sharp blade is a cleaner cut on the blade of grass. A cleaner cut means there is less 'pull' on the grass blade when it is cut causing less damage to the grass plant. It also make a more regular, sharper cut line on the grass blade which is more healthy for the grass plant and makes the freshly cut lawn look better. A dull mower blade is like using a broom stick for a mower blade. The speed and action would 'cut' the grass, but see how the motor bogs down when you do so and examine the grass blades after mowing. The ends of the grass blades will be frayed and stringy and in a day or two there will be a straw coloring across the lawn where the frayed ends have died and dried out.   A mower blade with a knife sharp edge will run much easier, give a more event cut, will leave the lawn looking more green in the days following a mowing and will be more healthy for the grass plant over it's life. Good video. You’ve helped me understand the difference between “high lift” lawn mower blades and mulching blades. This is a current discussion at our house. Yeah, we’re pretty exciting folks. 🙄 Anyway, I’ve been running Oregon G5 Gator mulching blades and though they certainly do cut the unusually thick grass we’ve had this Spring and early summer, they also have been leaving a thick row of expelled trimmings, which we have to then rake up. The mulching blades’ tab is split into fins. I never understood why until watching your video. It seems by splitting that tab into fins, there would be less lift thereby encouraging the grass to stay under the deck longer and get in contact with the blades more before being expelled and be expelled at less velocity. I have a set of high-lift blades being delivered today, so we will see if that is true. If so, our clippings with these new blades will get dispersed farther and hopefully not require raking. However, your comment on requiring more horsepower due to increased drag means we will need to mow slower (or increase our horsepower, which we can’t easily do). I have since been told to use the mulching blades in the Fall when leaves are falling and the high lift blades during the heart of mowing season. Who knew?

I really enjoy your videos Destin but on this one I think you’re wrong on several points.

1) The bent tabs are purely there to clear the cut grass out into the exit chute or collector. In fact on a flymo lawnmower the lift is the other way round to get the mower to hover over the ground. They cut just fine but just chew the cuttings up into a pulp to feed the lawn.

2) cutting is all to do with the resistance a blade of grass has to the incoming blade. When this exceeds the local strength of the grass it is severed. The grass can resist the incoming blade either by stiffness, damping or inertia forces. Stiffness can be overcome by a very sharp thin blade as in a scythe but a blunt edge moving very fast will predominantly be resisted by the inertia of the grass (resistance to get up to the speed of the blade due to the mass of the grass). Damping forces probably don’t contribute much.
Hence a strimmer which just uses a nylon cord is quite capable of cutting grass. No lift or sharpness required.

3) there are lawnmowers that do use shearing like scissors. Cylindrical mowers do just that where a rotating cylindrical blade cuts against a stationary lower blade over which the grass passes. There are also tractor driven cutters that operate just like a barbers trimmer.

I have two ideas.

Chain Saw:

I would like to see a chain saw cutting a log both with the grain and against the grain. And I would like to see it in slow motion where the chain saw is just cutting off a chain-width of wood so we can actually see the chain teeth cutting the wood. In other words, cut a log in two. Then just slice off a chain width of wood from the face of the log so we can see the teeth cutting. You might need a fixture to hold the chain saw accurately because it might be difficult to cut just a chain width off the face of a log by hand.

Do this in both directions. In other words, once against the wood grain, (like cutting normal firewood logs), and then once cutting length wise (i.e. along the the actual length of the log).

I'd like to see this because I know that the chips that come off are quite different. When cutting lengthwise the chips are very long and stringy, when cutting cross-grain the chips are more "normal" like cutting firewood.

There's also another direction I'm not sure what to call it. If you cut a firewood log, and then stand it straight up and cut down from the top straight down the resulting chips are extremely fine like dust. That's neither with the grain or against the grain. In fact, I don't even know what you would call that.

Sawmill:

My second idea is to do the same thing with bandsaw blades. It's not really yard equipment, but I have a portable bandsaw and I would like to see how the teeth cut on that too. Again, this could be filmed by just skimming off a single blade-width of wood which is easy to do on a sawmill.

The main thing with the sawmill blade would be to film the difference between blades that are designed for softwood and have a large angle to the cutting teeth, versus blades that are designed for hardwood that have a straighter angle to the cutting teeth.

Just suggestions.

The explanation of the "lift tab" seems a bit odd. If the tab trails edge is pointing away from the ground then there will be a low pressure zone under the blade, and a high pressure zone above the blade. If I were a piece of grass about to be hit, I would be should be pulled down to the under side; however, due to the air flow that is created by the blades, I am aligned vertically (not pulled up, but balanced by the air flow). So, the blades are designed such that the forces put on the grass by the air flow is more influential than the pressure zones; however the pressure zones still have a part to play, which is probably why we see the grass bend up and down, rather than hold a constant upright position. As I watch this, a lonely brain cell somewhere in my melon raised a hand and asked: Would a curved (scythe shaped) blade be more efficient in cutting grass versus the common straight edged blades we all use?
What I envisioned is a blade shaped somewhat like an "S". A moderately curved blade that would slice the grass more than simply hack through it. The common hand scythe (or sickle) demonstrates this efficient cutting action. How would a similar approach work for a mower.
I suspect it would be better for the "S" to spin counter clockwise to avoid grass bunching into one part of the blade, but it would be interesting to see it rotated in either direction.
Why am I curious about this? If a blade could be more efficient at cutting, the power necessary to cut could be reduced. This means a smaller engine could be implemented to cut more grass with less energy consumption. At least that is the theory I am running with.

Cylinder mowers (called reel mowers in the US) have opposing blades. One is fixed to the frame, the other is wrapped around the cylinder (usually 5 or more separate blades) and as they rotate they shear the grass between them selves and the fixed blade. They make a much neater cut, and for that reason are used on fine lawns, putting greens, tennis courts etc.

Actually there are mowers that cut like scissors. Reel mowers operate on this principle, with one set of revolving blades (the reel) and a stationary blade (the bedknife). As the reel spins it gathers bunches of grass and stands them up against the bebknife which it then sheers the grass. You can think of a reel mower as a set of "revolving scissors".
Not only does this allow you to cut lower than a rotary mower, the cut is almost always of higher quality and is less damaging to the plant. The downside is reel mowers require much more maintenance and sharping is far more time consuming and precise.

My grandfather's manual lawn mower worked like scissors. The grass bumped against a fixed rod and spinning blades cut off the grass against that rod. The force used to push the mower forward drives the inner blades, geared up for higher speed (and making it somewhat harder to push). Lots of physics again, a few tight tolerances, but quite different from a modern lawn mower.

A lawnmower blade spins at between 2500-3500 rpm and at these speeds it wil slice trough basically anything placed in front of it weather it is flexible or not. The grass will have no time to flex as the blade hits it at this speed with or without the airflow.  wich main purpose is instead I think to lift the grass straws up to be at the correct level with the blade  so it cuts the entire lawn to even height no matter if the grass  lays down or not. Robot mowers however have no such fan action cause the motor is not powerful enough to spin a such big blade. Instead a robot mower often use 3 razor sharp blades on a small metal disc in most cases however I have seen some such mowers with solid steel rotors as well. The lack of this fan action plus electric drive also make these mowers so quiet you cant even hear them operate (except for a faint hum). They are totally noise free. They however also seem to get the grass to an even height what I have seen.

Inertial Tear is more likely and the lift created by the tab is to help with transport to the discharge chute.  As a commenter mentioned below reel mowers work on this principle and provide the best "cut possible".  I.e. that is what golf courses use consistently.

Some and thoughts observations, to check if it really works on vacuum, you should also check if where does the air get sucked in from?
The grass is more likely to bounce back due to spring effect rather than vacuum. It's getting beaten down, it rises up for conservation of momentum. And when it's rising back it meets the blade and gets ripped.

Destin, the tab is there to create airflow that deals with the clippings. They need to be evacuated, especially if the grass is long. Otherwise it would just turn to chum and load up. The grass cuts because of Newton's second law. The momentum of the grass approaches zero in the limit → (inertia), and the force of the blade is extremely high in comparison. The blade shears the grass off against its own mass. I wouldn't be surprised if there was also a hydraulic and/or thermal rupture effect with very green/wet grass. Dry grass would lack this, and is also much less massive, but is more rigid and brittle like raw spaghetti.

OOH! Lawn mowers! SUB! As a professional lawn mowing guy for the last 18 years (and someone who is also very curious about science) you have piqued my curiosity! Incidentally, lawn mowers with cylinder blade systems behave similar to scissors. My main lawn mower has a spinning cylinder blade, comprising of six curved blades welded to a central axis, kind of like a "sextuple-helix" if you like. It rubs against a flat blade underneath and the grass that gets caught between the blades is cut very neat and is spit out the front into a catcher. As for rotary style machines like you demonstrated, the lift tab also spits the grass out into the exit chute or rear catcher. If the lift tabs are all worn out (which happens a lot for me) the blades will still cut the grass, but won't collect up the clippings, making it less efficient. I love your videos, by the way. Looking forward to the physics behind whipper snippers!!

You learn this by inference if you use a reel mower on a weedy yard. The reel mower uses a scissor action with littl lifting of the grass below the cut bar. Works, but soon you notice the grasses that have seed stalks that lay flat start to take over as they aren't cut. So, at least every few times, you need to use a rotary mower to lift the grass/weeds for a uniform cut.

I toyed with the idea of some kind of rake on the front of the reel mower to lift the grass/weeds that stayed low and avoid their taking over the yard. The ring of the slicing as the reel spins is very pleasant to me. Of course, the other alternative is aggressive invasive species abatement so that you have a putting green grass cover.

Destin, I'm very surprised that you made no mention of reel mowers in this entire video. I would want to think because you're too young to remember them, but I'm sure that's not the case. Also the bent up section on the end of the blade that you're calling a "tab" 4:45 was not added for many years after the rotary mower came onto the market. The rotary blade cuts the grass because of this little thing in physics called "inertia". The cutting blade is moving so fast that the grass blade can't move out of the way quickly enough due to that inertia. The bent up tab on the end of the blade makes the cut cleaner. Blades with those bent up tabs are also called mulching blades.
Virtually every golf course in the country mows the putting greens with reel mowers. Maybe you could do a video in your garden tool series on "reel mowers". Also a video on "scythes" would be very interesting. They are used to cut grass also and they do it entirely dependent on inertia.

@Destin. I think you are giving too much credit for cutting to the airflow. For example compare lawn mower vs. line trimmer same result AND no "designed air flow" The airflow is just about waste management ie grass discharge. The blade is effective due to the blade tip speed. This this is the potential energy vs. Momentum situation. Would you rather be hit by a 1000kg ball @ 1 m/s or 1kg ball @ 1000 m/s? Vacuum or atmospheric air pressure the result is the same the blade will sever the grass... Now whether it makes it to the bag or out the chute is all about the air flow. Try these two experiments: compare what you just did with and without a tab on the blade see if it still cuts. You will be surprised. The results will be the same as far as cutting is concerned.

The design of rotary style mowers are ingenious and well thought out.  However it would be wise to note that rotary mowers isn't exactly the cleanest cut or the most efficient. I am totally in favour of educating the people of the world, provided the information is correct. Also, I would not expect to get an informed answer to an analysis of a physics question from a barber.
Anyway, let us sort this confusion out as to what the purpose of the
tabs on the blade are primarily for. Did anyone notice the similarity of a mower with a tabbed blade and contoured chute to a centrifugal water pump? They both work on the same principle: the rotation of the blade causes the air and cut grass to be flung against the outside of the shaped chute then hurled into the catcher by centrifugal force, just as the vaned rotor of a centrifugal water pump sucks water in from the central inlet then by rapid rotation flings it out the outlet on the rim by centrifugal force. This is just basic physics and is not at all difficult to understand. Cheers.

Kinda surprised that you didn't realize that the mower blade was shaped kinda like a modified fan blade. The main purpose is to clear the cut grass, not to pull the grass up prior to cutting. As an comparison, you can make a lawn mower from a string trimmer and it still cuts about as well as a mower with blades, but it doesn't pick up the grass and throw it into a catcher or out of a chute on the side. As for why the grass stands up after the blade passes, you seem to have assumed that this is due to air movement, but the grass will naturally stand up in order to assume a minimal strain position. I'm not convinced that those mower blades are producing enough air movement to make a blade of grass move that quickly. I suspect that's more due to strain release and the air flow is simply there to clear the cut grass.

I'd like you to show the difference in how a modern lawn mower works vs an old school manual mower. I'm talking about the type of mower with the helix shaped blades the rotate against a stationary edge. These old school mowers and modern mowers work VERY differently, and the older style ones actually make much cleaner cuts and keep the lawn healthier. Modern mowing equipment used on golf courses use this old school style helix blade for a reason... look at you grass tips a day or two after being mowed, and you'll see a bit of dead material. They featured Rodney on our local TV station last week.  Another thing, besides the vacuum effect that draws the grass upwards is that even that blade of grass has inertia.  Anything at rest will tend to stay at rest unless acted upon by an outside force.  You can see some of the blades of grass bend backwards over the top of the mower blade.  The wind resistance adds to that "at rest" inertia at the top of the blade of grass.

Nope.

The tab isn't lifting the grass Infront of it, the tab is lifting the grass behind it, as the tab passes it forces air up, this in turn pulls the grass up behind it and the blade coming behind the tab cuts it and that blade's tab does the same. Ultimately the tab is creating high pressure above the blade and low pressure behind/below the back of the blade, the grass has no choice but to be lifted.
If there was no tab it would cut grass, just not very well as the grass would lay down and stay laying down.

I just finished mowing. I was thinking about my previous question, and I'd like to rephrase it. What's more at the heart of my question is this: What techniques would help me use the least amount of energy to mow my lawn? I was thinking that even if I knew the absolute shortest path, there would be errors involved each time. Perhaps one day the truck is parked in the driveway and I have to maneuver around it.
So, what would be more helpful to me is to consider techniques for the best way to handle common situations like mowing around convex or concave angles, mowing around circular landscaping, mowing under a four-foot-ish deck, mowing on a hill... Keep in mind, I'm not whining here. I know how to get my whole yard mowed. I want to know the most energy-efficient techniques for getting it mowed.

Destin, you could also raise the deck of your riding mower, let the blades get up to speed, and then gradually lower the blades, 1/2' at a time. And then again, but drop from high to lowest as fast as possible. These 2 views would give you some varied results and data to observe. Also could stomp the grass down, depressing it, and film the grass' reaction to the suction of the blades vs. the natural rebound time of grass.

Another idea would be to build a shallow bed with transplanted grass and film from below to see the edge. Is the grass affected as the mower deck arrives, when it comes under the deck.

I had experimented in a much less scientific way as a kid, I tried comparing freshly mowed grass blade to cuts I made with scissors, scissors swung without holding the grass, scissors swung while holding the grass above, a knife with a slicing motion (angled from the blade's axis), a knife with a "chopping" motion (perpendicular to the blade) and ripping with my bare hands just pulling them between my fingers in various ways. I found some blades were cut like with the knife, others were more similar to when I laid a blade of grass across my index and pulled it apart using my ring finger and thumb on each side to create a wedge with my index finger. So I figured it was a combination of those two things that worked, that the blade of the lawn mower would sometimes cut through cleanly but the blade it couldn't would get slapped against the blade from the momentum and tear from not being able to move quickly enough to avoid the damage.

the proof is in your own video.
1 the lawn mower blade (lmb) goes by the blade of grass (bog)
2 the (bog) gets knocked down
3 the (bog) pops back up and gets hit by the next (lmb) goes by
4 repeat until the (bog) is finally snapped/cut/bisected
THEN the vacuum/draft caused by the 'notch' on the (lmb) picks up the detached portion of the (bog), spins it around inside the mower deck until centrifugal force hurls the (bog) out onto your yard or where ever. Right?

I don't think it's shear stress. imagine the molecular level, grass molecules all lined up, along come the (lmb) molecules and they are SHARP. at the point of contact if the (lmb) is sharp then the pressure at the point of contact is high and the molecular bonds of the grass are broken. if the (lmb) is dull then some bonds are broken and the blade is not cut or it 'hangs' on the (lwb) and is torn. not enough room to explain fully (my belief.)

Maybe it's the time pressure to produce more content, but the analyses seem to be getting more and more superficial. (It could also be that the simpler phenomena are being exhausted.) Here, for example, the tabs are at too high of an angle of attack to apply a conventional lift explanation. A better question would be: Why does the mower continue to work when the tabs would be stalled in the inertial reference frame of the lawn? A few ideas suggest themselves. First, the tabs may be behaving as a rudimentary radial flow pump. IOW, the radial flow may dominate. Second, grass clippings + air put us squarely in the realm of two-phase flow. The clippings impacting the tabs and being flung upward drag air along with them, and this may be a significant contribution to the flow. Third, and finally for now, the blade operates at the interface of the lawn and the clippings. The blades of grass are going to slow the flow relative to the blade on the underside. One could imagine this (somehow) sucking the clippings back down into the lawn, were it not for the disruptive effect of the tabs, for example by the aforementioned impact dynamic, or through vortex shedding and entrainment. The latter two would contribute to radial and tangential flow that further the hypothesis of "crude centrifugal pump."

At some point, the value proposition of Smarter Every Day shifts from "smarter" to "feeling smarter." I hope it stays with the former, though the pressures of the medium probably conspire toward the latter.

Hover mowers.  There's an outstanding British product called the FlyMo.  I believe the patent has expired, so there are now other competing designs of hover mowers.  This design uses airflow not simply to lift the grass, but also to create a high pressure region under the deck to lift it off the ground.  These mowers are completely wheelless, and so work very well in tight spaces, on steep hillsides, and so on.  I'm not sure if you want to get such a machine, or if you did how exactly you would video it (Cut a hole in the deck and fit a window made from high impact polycarb?  Run it on a sheet of clear acrylic and video from underneath?), but it may be something worth looking into.

This is why there are low/medium/high lift and mulch blades. If you live in a sandy or lose soil area you want low lift so you don't just suck up all the sand/dirt. On a normal lawn you want high lift to pull the grass up straight to be cut. Mulch blades suck the most to provide the speed to send the grass clippings to your bag system.

Okay, so I was thinking about building my own robotic lawn mower because the commercial ones are too expensive. I didn't understand why we needed rotating blades, driven by a motor that uses a lot of energy. I was thinking that a hedge-trimmer mechanism, which is similar to a hair clipper, could do the job just as well. I was wrong. But in the process of figuring that out, I found that there's a consortium of people who maintain golf courses and do research about the science involved in cutting grass. It had to do with how much energy the blade has to impart to the grass to split the fibers, etc. I wish I could find it now, but if you look for it, there's a quite a bit of data on this subject, which explains why we use rotating blades as opposed to clipper-style blades. I still think clippers could be made to work if they were re-designed, as opposed to re-purposed from a hedge trimmer.
Also, the only way to make your lawn carbon-neutral is to have a machine mowing it, because a human will exhale more carbon just waking around the lawn than the grass is able to sequester. Obviously, the mowing machine has to work on electricity, so it's zero-emissions, and the electricity would have to be generated by renewables in order for this to work.

A couple of observations:

1. There are mowers that cut like scissors. Reel mowers, most commonly in the form of manual push mowers, use conventional sheering to cut. The curved, rotating blade cage is just half of a scissor shear, and also acts to lift the grass up to shear.

2. Your blades are too dull. If you see ripping and frayed ends on your cut grass, the blade isn't sharp enough. Do another video pass with freshly sharpened blades, and you'll see. The sharp edge will also help your overall aerodynamic profile, and increase the lift of the grass.

The Slo Mo Guys did a nice video of using a katana to cut through water bottles, which is the type of cutting action your rotary mower uses. Of course, the bottles don't need lift to stand up to be cut, but the sharpness of the blade is critical, else you end up batting bottles around with a steel bar, basically.

Hi Destin, I always wondered when I cut higher grass with a trimmer, why the cutted grass stays long when using the 3-bladed metal cutter but is smashed in small pieces when using the plastic cord. I have an idea why it is like that, but it would be great to see it in high speed.

My mower came with two blades - a cut blade, and an ejection blade. The cut blade is flat, has no wing, and static air pressure holds the grass up long enough for the rotating blade to make severe impact damage (cut/rip) - this is the same concept as you can see with a nylon string on a weed whacker. The second "ejection" blade type has the "wing" that you talk about. That wing creates centrifugal airflow that drags the loose bits of grass to the outside of the deck and out the chute. The wing has no effect on holding the grass up - it actually does the opposite as the centrifugal airflow reduces the air pressure on one side of the grass and causes it to lay flatter. You get a much neater and more even cut with the flat "cut-only" blade.

A strimmer (chord type) would be interesting as there is no uplift tab, everything is flexible (grass, wire/chord), isn’t enclosed to create a vacuum (my shins are testament to that!), and yet is a brutal piece of equipment capable of destroying and moving anything in its way (within reason).

Not sure I agree with the idea of suction helping to cut the grass, firstly suction from below the grass would only be early on in the cycle then the low pressure system under the blade would draw air in from around the outside of the mower deck causing a horizontal flow not an updraft. Secondarily if it was necessary for the airflow like this then all mowers would share the same design. Many tractor slashers etc, have flat or near flat blades at the end of flat square sections,  spinning circular inside a square housing, not creating any real airflow. I think mostly design of those blades is to improve discharge by directing the cut grass irrespective of airflow to reduce the need to cut longer pieces many times therefore reducing horsepower etc. Would love to see the difference in slow-mo with a mower in a vacuum, or flat blades vs curved blades or even wing shaped laminar flow designed blades.

Hi Justin,
Thanks for the video but I feel that the air flow lift is not the crucial part of the lawn cutting mechanism.
consider a weed wacker (wipper snipper) etc there is no lift and the blade (nylon) is even blunter than the lawn mower blade.
the Weed Wacker line cuts by the inertial action of the grass refusing to bend out of the way and so is sheared by the line. no vacuum is involved. the lawn mower blade is the same principal but with a twist.
The Tab on the lawn mower blades are used to create an air flow (not a vacuum) to eject the grass cuttings.
many mowers without grass catchers, possibly older machines - "Victa Mowers", never had tabs because they did not need to collect the cuttings. These mowers cut grass equally well, if not better than blades with tabs. These mowers actually had vents just under the central motor that let air into the under deck area and the air flow was from these vents and down to the outer edges of the deck and out radially, actually oppose to the vacuum that you spoke of.

Interesting your mower that you cut the front edge away did not cut the grass as well for a very specific reason and I propose that the reason is the confinement of the grass. As the front edge of the mower deck moves forward it bends the grass blades forward causing the grass blades to flex forward. The bent over grass is stiffer and restrained, much like you holding the top edge of the grass and then slashing the section between your hand and the ground.
I believe it is this action that presents the grass blades to the mower blade tips for cutting.

If in your trial you maintained the bottom leading edge of the cutting deck and only made a hole in the top to video the cutting action, the bottom edge would of performed normally and so would have been the cutting action.

the vacuum aspect is only secondary to the restraint the front edge of the cutting deck has on cutting performance.

in your video that showed the grass raising up, the grass raised because it flexed up returning to its original shape somewhat.
