Destin, there are several different kinds of mowers. Rotary blade mowers are just one type, and the most common you see. You mentioned barbers clippers as an example, well there are mowers made just like that. They are called sickle bar mowers. They work and function just like gas powered hedge trimmers. There are also reel mowers, which also use a stationary bar with rotating blade assembly. Look them both up. Not much to see on them recorded at high speed, but they are just another type of mower. There are also flail mowers, which basically beat, or break the grass off. You usually see that type mowing ditches, or corn stalks after harvest.

Talking about not knowing the tab was for suction, did you know a mulching blade is designed to cause the flow of air in the deck to recirculate the grass clipping back into the blade over and over to keep chopping them up? There are lots of different types of blades. You might want to do this video over using a clear window so as not to disrupt the air flow. Might also require lighting, but that could be done.
Also, on multiple blade decks, they have dividers, or baffles, between the blades. They affect air flow. Without them, the deck leaves strips between the blades.

How about fan style grass seeders? The ones you buy for spreading grass seed aren't that impressive, but in the agriculture world, the fan spreaders have a lot of adjustment to spread evenly. Different weighted seeds and fertilizers will spread differently depending on what position they are dropped into the fan. You have to change the drop point in order to get an even spread.

Sprayers are interesting too. Different nozzles to affect liquid droplet size, and width of spray to control drift.

I'm not convinced (I don't think you proved your hypothesis). It's entirety possible that the tensile strength of the blade of grass itself provides enough support to allow the lawnmower blade to shear at the typical rotational speed of a lawnmower blade. In other words: the blade of grass is stiff enough it can be sheared by a blade moving 200 mph without any additional lift to support it. I think the sole purpose of the airflow produced by the blade is to move waste out of the mower.

To really test your hypothesis you would have to compare the efficacy of the lawnmower blade as designed vs modified to remove any lift (by cutting that little upwards flap thing off). I would love to see this revisited.

Oh, and I think my hypothesis is supported by the fact that a weed-wacker works just fine, and I don't see how a spinning piece of string could create significant lift.

Sorry Destin, I cannot watch this any longer that 1:36 minutes in. I am too old. I remember when the only consumer level mowers did use opposing shear line technology, which was necessary for a human powered hand reel type mower. Those reel blades shear the grass just like you scissors do.
The crappy engine powered lawn mower you ride, or your neighbor pushes, is a product of 1950's cost cutting for consumers. That was when retailers like Sears began selling a much cheaper version of the Toro mower, itself a cheaper way of engine powering a mower. Engine powered mowers with reels were only affordable to professionals and golf courses back then.
So what made you think that all consumer grade powered mowers always used single rotor blade tip velocity as a standard?
you never knew it to be different. My Dad bought my brother and I a Sears rotary mower when we were teens because of the cheap price and our promise to pay him back by mowing neighbors lawns for money. We hated the push mower, a reel type that needed fine adjustment to keep it shearing smoothly, but that we tended to just tighten the fixed blade enough to stay cutting reasonably well and almost never oiled. That motorized mower, even from Sears, the Walmart of its day, cost a lot more than a reel mower, the standard at that time. Gas acquisition to operate it and the cantankerous starting with a rope pull, made it as much of a maintenance chore as its manual counter-part, but it did make the cutting itself easier. Its noise was not appreciated by neighbors either. Cheapness and consumption, replacement of the poor quality engine and gumming up of the spark plug from the leaded gas were endemic. They have improved in reliability, but adding driving and riding once every body began to think of paying for them as normal, means we have forgotten a type of mower that can last a lifetime and give oneself good exercise as well as do a crisper sheared lawn surface more akin to a golf course.

It's similar to the reason why if you are standing on the ground, and get hit by a car, you will likely have your legs broken, because the car is traveling fast enough, and your legs are "anchored" by gravity at your feet to the ground (_your body wants to go 'down'_), that your legs don't move "with" the car on impact fast enough to displace your legs (_body trying to go down, car trying to go 90 degrees sideways_), so the legs bend/break.

If you jump and make that "anchor point" at your feet non--existent, your legs will be in mid air and the car can "push" your legs with much less resistance (_your body is no longer trying to go down_), hence less damage to you .

Same thing happens in American Football/rugby when someone gets tackled, they are anchored to the ground and the impact is worse compared to if they were in the air.

Especially when you have your mower deck set up for mulch or push bagging discharged cut grass into a bag. You probably would have had better footage from installing mulch blades because of the increased pitch or bent blade for greater surface area lift due to the nature of the process of mulching your cut grass. The cut grass blade is actually cut repeatedly before it’s finished the cycle of the cut. Due to the area that I live, generally I only change to mulching blades closer towards the closing of grass growth season. This way I have a insulated blanket over my yards grassed area through the cold or winter months. It really makes a difference when spring comes around and my grass is greener and not overwhelmed with crab grass or weeds..One thing for certain, your mowers blades are extremely dull. Be sure you got your blade balancer stand before you get to sharpening them. I always get a new set. Take the old ones off, install the new set and then later on I sharpen the old set. That way if you messed up sharpening by taking to much off and having a blade balancing issues you still have had your yard work done. Lol

I’d first like to say this was a really cool video being able to see all that in slow-mo. Truthfully though I think just about everyone here is overthinking the blade tab. It’s essentially there to help evacuate the clippings through the discharge chute. If you look at any 3 point mower for a front loader tractor the blades are perfectly flat with no tab. Why? Because there is no discharge chute therefore a blade which helps create lift  would be pointless.
The vacuum/lift has been severely reduced with the big gapping hole cut into the deck
So then how does a fully manual push mower work? Those blades aren't moving quickly enough to cause a sort of inertial tear, or to generate lift.

One of the first industrial farm machines for cutting was to replace scything, called the Allen scythe. a wheeled, gas operated reciprocating cutter designed exactly like what a hair clippers looks like. There were already reciprocating mower heads, but they were larger, animal drawn machines that generated reciprocation from gearing. These were not faster than professional scythemen, but they were cheaper. The farmer and his horse could do it in about as much time for a fraction of the expense. They were heavy rigs though, and not great on undulating terrain. The Allen scythe was the compromise. It was just as fast as horse drawn harvesters, and could go wherever a man could.

This is why it's important to keep the caked-on grass cleaned off the underneath side of the deck. Even a shallow layer can disrupt the aerodynamics involved, resulting in beating or chewing the grass as opposed to neatly slicing through it, as the blade is engineered to work with that toroidal channel molded into the deck.
Also, your discharge chute would seem to have the same problem as the chopped-out section of the first deck, i.e., its airflow is different than the opposite side that's enclosed under the deck. To get a really good view, you could replace that chopped-out section with plexiglass, and even light it from underneath with a strip of LED lights for better photography. For even better lighting, erect a light-blocking tent around the mower and mow a short strip, with only the LED and camera lighting illuminating the grass.

The size of the tab on the blade and the deck design make a HUGE difference in cutting performance. A low lift (small tab) blade, also called a mulching blade does not pull the grass up as well and it also does not discharge it as well, leading to a clogged deck in tall or wet grass.

I am currently looking for a high lift (large tab) blade for my Ariens GT20 because the medium lift blade on it does a poor job, but I think deck design may also play a role. My Cub Cadet 982 cuts like a dream, even in tall thick wet grass.

Rotary Lawn mowers with horizontal blades, either fixed or floating and flail mowers basically work using inertia.  The airflow isn't designed to lift grass so much as clear the cuttings from the blade area.  The speed of contact is the critical thing.  The inertia means the grass can't get out of the way fast enough.  Weed eaters with nylon string work on exactly the same principle except they use angular momentum to push the cuttings away from the work area and of course nylon string isn't sharp for the most part.  Reel mowers and Sickle mowers work on the "scissor principle" but the speed of contact is far slower than a rotary.  Reel mowers fell out of favour because they require high levels of maintenance to keep the blades sharp and the fact that they struggle with some tough fibrous grasses such as Paspalum.  Reels are favoured by Golf courses and the like because of their ability to cut close, give the best finish and are much more gentle on sensitive small blade grasses that are favoured in that sort of use case. Sickle mowers are favoured in Agriculture because they don't throw the grass away and the pickup can be controlled by a gathering system.  That's how a Combine Harvester works.  Get a camera inside one of those!

The blade fin and airflow help move, recut, mulch, and eject the cut grass but I'm not convinced that it alone sucks it up straight to make a straight cut. It helps, though. Healthy grass has moisture and mass / inertia to resist getting knocked down but gets snapped over and broken against a fast moving sharp edge. The fins are for airflow to recirculate the grass and cut it multiple times.

Regarding the airflow, I had more or less come to the same conclusion in my years of landscape maintenance, but from a different approach. The mowers I use are equipped for bagging, rather than discharge. I noticed VERY early on that if the chute ever got plugged, either from wet grass or the bag simply getting too full, the grass on the ground would always be cut unevenly, effecting the quality of my work. My conclusion was that without airflow, the grass would always be pushed sideways with the motion of the blade, rather than pulled up (where you get the best cut), because lift requires somewhere for the air to go.

This isn't to say that booklearnin' won't get you the right answer, just that when you've got both booklearnin' and experience from which to infer, you get the right answer that much faster.

I don't fault you for not noticing this sooner. It's a lesson I have to teach EVERY new employee I hire, because it's not something that the average homeowner really has cause to think about. They will usually cut when it's dry, and clogging won't be an issue (unless they let their grass grow too long), where as I have to cut on a schedule all week long (regardless of the weather), and clogging up is a constant issue whenever it's wet.

It also helps if your blades are sharp. I usually try to sharpen mine every about every three weeks or so, since I cut people's lawns for a living. Any more frequently, and I'd be replacing them too often (let alone that maintenance takes a lot of time out of my day as it is - even new equipment needs to be maintained when you're using it everyday).

This topic had always intrigued me. Here is my attempt at explaining:

I believe that Destin is half right about the airflow lifting the blade. In the case of those fancy clippers, the airflow lifts the hair so that it is positioned correctly for the two blades to shear it off. In the case of the mower, the airflow also merely positions the blade of grass so that it can be cut. The cutting comes from the inertia of the blade of grass as it bends over the mower blade. The mower blade tries to accelerate the entire blade of grass by applying a force at a localized point. This force that is required to accelerate the blade of grass creates tension in the grass causing it to tear. It could be analogous to hanging a wet spaghetti noodle by one end and chopping it in half with a somewhat blunt object (e.g. dull side of knife blade, or perhaps even the handle of the knife).

Yes!! Finally a topic on which I know a thing or two. Wish you talked more about airflow as it is really the key to how a mower cuts. On a properly set up mower deck the blades are about a quarter inch lower in the front than in the back. This draws air in the back and then the spinning blades force the air out the chute. Commercial grade mowers always have deeper decks than residential mowers. Deeper decks move a larger volume of air and remove grass clippings faster. If the mower deck is constantly clogged up with grass the mower can't lift the grass and cut it properly. This results in poor cut quality. Hope to see more videos on the topic.

I'm going to pile on a few other responses to say that it is an inertia cut, and that the lift tabs are for a mulching blade. It lifts the already cut grass to float it around and re-cut it before it goes out the chute. A thatching blade has a fork- or rake-like flare that points down, to drag along the lawn and tear up thatching so the lawn can breathe/drink. Many rotating lawn-mower blades are just flat, and work for the same reason a weed-whacker works.
The aha moment is that when the blade comes around the front of the mower, what doesn't get cut is knocked down, and as you continue, the blade comes around in the back of the mower across the grass the opposite direction. This lifts the grass back up, and cuts it evenly. This is why you get a better overall cut when you only take 'half-bite' - the blade is traversing the grass the opposite direction the next pass. The left side knocks the grass forward, and on your next lap, the right side of the mower lifts it back up and cuts it off evenly.

How would the blades be generating lift if there's nowhere for the air to go vertically? I think the tabs act like a centrifugal fan, pushing air outwards to exhaust the clippings not generating lift. Also grass will spring back up on its own, it doesn't need a lift force to put it in the way of the blade. I think the interaction is simpler: once the blade moves fast enough the blade the inertia of the blades of grass is sufficient to generate a cutting force. Basically on the time scale of that interaction, the grass is quasi-rigid and the blade can exert enough force to cut the grass. If it goes too slowly the grass has time to move and the blade just pushes instead of cutting.

I would be interested in seeing a video(or segment) on the old school rotary style lawn mowers(the sort of barrel shaped ones with no motor.)
I used to do lawn care(fertilizer, pesticides, etc.), and every class I took(often from people with post grad degrees in agronomics) and all my bosses, and everything I've ever read claimed that those are actually superior to the tradition walk-behind/ride-on spinning blade mowers.
supposedly they cut the grass much cleaner, as opposed to tearing the grass the way rotary mowers can do(if you look closely in this video, you can see the blades of grass are often raggedy at the ends after being cut(though this could possibly be due to a dull mower blade.))
this is bad because it hurts the appearance of the lawn(the tips are stringy and discolored), and also because it causes the plant to use more energy fixing the "wound", does more damage to the cells, causes a greater loss of moisture, and in particular makes the grass much more susceptible to disease(just like how getting your hand cut off by a shark, or chainsaw is more likely to become infected(due to the much larger surface area of exposed tissue) than getting your hand cut off by saw, a single clean slice by a very sharp samurai sword.))
however, I do not know why the rotary mowers cut more efficiently. I doubt they cause much of the suction you refer to in this video, and I can't help but think the blades are traveling far slower. it also seems like each section(or even blade) of grass would only have one chance to get cut with a rotary mower, whereas the rotating blade mowers(even though the cutting surface of the blade is only a few inches long at the extreme end of each side of the blade) has several chances to cut each blade(depending on how fast you are going) and thus is less likely to leave little "mohawks" of uncut grass behind.)
I suppose it could be due in part to the fact that the blades on rotary mowers are moving more or less straight in into the grass(almost like a scythe) whereas the blades on the type of mower in this video are rotating in an angular fasion, and may be more likely to "rip" the blade as opposed to making a clean cut, but since the blade is moving so fast, and the moment of contact between the blade and any individual piece of grass is so incredibly brief, I can't help but think that the direction/way the blades are moving would make no difference(if the blades were cutting right near the center of blade, where the linear velocities would be lower, then maybe.)
the only other thing I can think of is that maybe the blades on drum style rotary mowers are sharper(please sharpen your mower blades regularly people), possible due to them being just simple pieces of think stamped metal(at least I think they're stamped, i could be wrong.)

Hey destin. I'm a farmer. We use both reciprocating blades and rotating blades for different purposes. The 'hair trimmer' style blade is called a sickle or cutter bar and is used for crops that have thicker stems and that need to have their tops protected from being beaten up, because they have seeds on them for example. This is what a windrower or swather will use to cut crops being harvested for seed. It's also what is used on the large headers used to feed crop into the massive combine harvesters that harvest wheat.

We do use rotary style heads to harvest hay and grass for feed, however. They're much faster and the tops aren't full of precious seed we want to delicately handle.

So for example, a rotary swather/windrower might cut alfalfa or Bermuda above 5mph, sometimes closer to 10 or even 15 mph. A combine harvester in wheat, or a windrower in a seed crop will go much closer to 2 or 3 mph.

So on the push mower the airflow comes from a combination of the deck AND the blade. Like you said, when you cut the front off the push mower the airflow would be all jacked up. Also, while a lot of landscapers will cut with there discharge shoots up, in my opinion(and experience) it seems to have the same effect of cutting the front off of the push mower. Less proper airflow(I say proper here because its engineered and tested to with the discharge shoot down) on that side of the deck. Also the "tab" on the mower blade makes a massive difference in the cut quality and lift. The blade you show at 4:45 is a high-lift blade and the one of the larger mower looks like an all in one, mulching and discharge blade. So on the blades on that bigger mower would have much less lift. On a side note, I have used super high lift blades before and all of the brands I have tried seem to be a bit lighter(thinner gauge metal) than my mowers standard blades. So that counteracts the increased airflow causing strain on a spindle.

My suggestion would be do to a see through plastic cover on the place you cut off of the push mower and try that again with that high lift blade. Just make sure to mold that plastic cover to the shape of the original metal to keep the airflow as it was designed and tested. And get some freshly sharpened blades :D

The tabs on blades don’t have to do with lift. The blades that have bigger tabs are used for bagging because it helps to throw the grass and move it up and away from under the deck. There’s blades that have tabs pointing down. Those ones are for mulching, aka, pushing the grass back into the ground. So the understanding that they (the tabs) stand up the grass blade up would be incorrect.
The blades cut grass because if you have a stationary object (relatively stationary) and a blade moving super fast, it will cut whatever is in its way. It will not need the grass to be held.

Edit: it is possible that the tabs cause a slight amount of lift but not enough to be concerned about. Blades with bigger tabs cut better because they clear the cut grass out from under the deck faster or more efficient then say a blade without tabs

The mower deck and blade are a system to work together to cut the grass. The deck is composed of smooth curves to direct the air and cut grass. The blade is shaped to also direct air besides a sharp edge to cut the grass. The blade cuts by momentum like a string trimmer.

So this doesn't explained how a scythe or swing blade or even a string trimmer is able to work.

For a 26" blade on a lawnmower running at 3,600 RPM, the tip velocity is a little over 278 miles per hour.  Think about it, in a just a little over an hour, the tips of your blade are going to travel  through a strip of grass the distance the length of Alabama top to bottom.  Notice how most used blades don't seem broken or chipped, but melted.  That is because the friction of the grass on the metal at those speeds does gradually melt away the metal and is why it is better to cut your grass with a sharp blade, AND when the grass is slightly damp (you don't want to cut while totally wet because it will just create a mess and grass clogs).  The cooling effect of the water will minimize the burning off of metal and you can literally go years without having to sharpen or replace the blade, barring hitting debris like rocks and such while cutting your yard.  I also noticed your grass tips look a little tattered as a result of using a dull blade. Not good. You want the grass to have good clean cut edges to minimize entry of bacteria and fungi, which will produce healthier looking grass.  Keep those blades sharp!  I replace my blades approximately every 4 or 5 years, and when I do, they still look pretty sharp.

This is a fascinating video! I'm not convinced that the slow-mo gives any evidence to your assertion that the lift tabs are pulling up the blades of grass to provide tension, though. Looking at individual blades, it looks more like the mower blade is hitting each grass blade multiple times and it's simple blunt force trauma (inertial forces) that is doing the cutting.

If the lift tab is what allows the cutting to work, then wouldn't it follow that all mower blades MUST have them. You can get blades that don't have lift tabs and they cut just fine. That wouldn't make sense if the tabs are integral to the cutting action itself.

My understanding of the lift tabs is that is what is responsible for "lifting" the cut pieces of grass -- AFTER it is cut. So you can get blades with low-angle tabs which are good for mulching or just shooting the clippings out the side, or you can get "high lift" blades with more pronounced tabs that are typically used with riding mowers that need to shoot the clippings down a long tube into a bagger.

In the end, it's a thought provoking experiment but one that would require a lot more testing to show that the physics are working quite like you assert, I think.

Hey Destin, great video. If I understand you correctly, you have come to the conclusion that it is the air flow which holds the grass blades up for the cut, the same way you did, with your hand, in the demonstration at the beginning of the video. Please correct me if I am wrong on that. Looking at it from my experience, and knowledge of a fairly limited range of physics, the air flow creates enough lift to make the grass stand straighter than normal, though I do not believe that the air flow has enough strength to literally hold the blades up as they are being cut.  The mower blade has a tendency to push the blades of grass out of its way, but the faster that mower blade is moving, the greater the energy required to accelerate the blades of grass out of the way, until the energy required to cut the grass is less than the energy required to accelerate it out of the mower blades path. Now the way a mulching deck works, you may notice that they tend to have a deeper, rounded area around the perimeter of the deck. The mulching blade creates enough air flow that it forms a vortex in the rounded area, and repeatedly circulates the grass cuttings through the blade until the pieces no longer have sufficient sail area to be held in the vortex, and they fall to the ground. Many multi purpose decks do not have that chamber around the perimeter, and are less efficient at mulching than a dedicated mulching deck. I do not have the background to be able to explain this all in proper physical terms. If you decide to go further in to this, whether it is to say why I am wrong, or just to better explain the physics, I would certainly be interested. I have no emotional stake in being right.

Hey @SmarterEveryDay I’m a product development engineer for a company that develops (amongst many many other things) Garden power tools.
The blade does create lift but this is mainly for airflow within the bowl to transport cut grass efficiently into the grass bag. Some mowers use blades without a lifted tip and still cut (just doesn’t fill a grass bag up very well), the sculpted shape of the bowl is also optimised to help with this.

We have taken a few slow motion videos of this, what seems to happen as someone here suggests is that on the first pass of the cutter blade it hits a blade of grass which just bats it out of the way and bends it. But the grass itself springs back up and the other end of the cutter blade slices it as it now has an opposing force.
Loved the video though, keep them coming! I’d suggest looking at Hedgecutters, Chainsaws and Shredders. The physics of these tools is fascinating!

I noticed the TIC clock in the background (ThinkGeek sells it, which is where I got mine).  Fun fact, it will not work if you plug in a DC power supply.  The electronics inside need a low voltage AC sinewave because they took the route that most cheap/hotel desktop clocks take:  Just use the 60Hz from the line to tell time (in North America at least).   More than that, it won't display the time!  The timing also drives the internal animation circuitry.  With DC you just get a blank display.

There is a lot more to a lawnmower than most people realize, and it’s nice to see more people seeing the years of trial and error, experimenting, great thought, and years of tweaks that go into them. (Especially from a great slow motion perspective like you are able to show!)
Let me add some light to this topic if you will.

Reel mowers do cut in a similar way to scissors. They are also better for the grass as they cut without ripping and tearing, which makes the grass more susceptible to disease. (That would actually be an interesting sight, slow motion of a reel mower cutting grass 😊)

And it may not seem like it but yeah there is a lot of thought that goes into mower decks as well as the blades.
The blade is actually quite similar to an aircraft wing, just with a sharpened leading edge.
They are tilted slightly (the only part of most blades that are parallel to the ground is in the middle of it where it bolt to the crankshaft or spindle) so the whole blade produces lift, not just the trailing edge. The trailing edge is to add some more lift but also to aid in removing clippings/mulching depending on blade style. Look at some mulching blades (Gator Blades for example) the trailing edge of those are much different, with multiple up curved tips to cause a sort of vortex effect/rotation of the clippings inside the deck to chop up each blade of grass multiple times.

And the deck keeps the airflow where it needs to go, directing it and the clippings to be blown out or kept circulating to be mulched (along with keeping the grass and the inevitable stone from flying all over the place lol)
If you can find a way to safely show the difference of a spinning blade in the deck as opposed to not in a deck that would be quite interesting, but be SUPER careful!! A mower blade is not a toy and will chop fingers/arms/toes/feet off easily!)

Anyways, I look forward to more videos on this! 😊
Take care!!

Dustin sounds like you need to clean your carburetor on your zero turn. When you are at an idle you can hear the motor 'hunting'  what is happing is the main idle circuit in the carburetor is plugged or restricted so the governor is trying to keep the engine running by increasing the rpm then when it does come up to RPM the governor stops and the idle circuit is supposed to keep it running at the minimum RPM, but since it is clogged or restricted if falls to a low of an RPM and the governor kicks back in. A very simple carb clean will take care of it.

face palm Look into the difference between a standard mower blade and a mulching mower blade.

A standard mower blade has a slight curve to almost the entire blade, which creates a lot of lift. This lift helps to vacuum up the grass, but it also helps to discharge the grass to the bag or the discharge chute.

A mulching mower blade has that extreme curve on the ends not to create lift (it actually creates very little lift), but to recirculate the grass within the mower deck multiple times to chop up the grass into small parts, thus helping to increase the speed at which they degrade, putting nutrients back into the soil.

Take a standard cutting blade, put some grass clippings on the sidewalk and run the mower with a bag/side discharge over them. Then use a mulching blade. The standard blade will move far more of the clippings than a mulching mower.

I don't think airflow or the updraft of a blade has that much to do with it.  They make what are called "no lift" blades without the updraft tabs for places that are rocky/sandy so that it doesn't destroy the mower.  I used to work near a beach where it was super sandy and that's what we used - still cut the grass just fine.  I think most of the cutting has to do with the speed of the blade.  The sheering force of the blade's cutting edge contacts the grass faster than the grass can bend out of the way.  It's the whole 'an object at rest tends to stay at rest until acted upon' thing.  If it were just the updraft, how would a mower cut grass that was too tall to stand straight up underneath it?
Timelapse of weedkiller. Or slow mo of weedwhacker

All impact cutting mowers cut grass through the very high speed of the blade, the grass just doesn't have time to accelerate out of the way, before it's cut off. Like shooting a pencil through a door, the moving object cuts the stationary one. Look at how much damage occurs to a car parked on the shoulder when hit by another, the moving vehicle is less damaged. The blades don't even need to be sharp, although it does a neater job if they are, just look at a flail mower with blunt hammers that will demolish anything that gets in the way!
The air flow only helps with standing up lying grass for a more even cut and clearing the grass after it's cut, out of the side chute or into a grass bag etc. High speed impact is all that's required, thus string trimmers, weed wackers or whatever you like to call them, cut just fine, with no air lifting the grass, although lying grass can get a bit messy.

Destin, if you notice, most deck tops are a duct that increases in volume as it approaches the exit area. Would be interesting to install a Magnhelic gage on top of the deck to check for how much the upper deck area differs in pressure than the slight vacuum created under the deck.

@smartereveryday I love you channel, excellent video. BUT.... I wonder if you're incorrect in thinking the upwards airflow is what 'holds' the grass to be cut. Yes, the airflow is there, but I think it is more to generate the 'vacuum' effect to move the cut grass into the bag or ejected out of the mower.

I wonder if the grass isn't simply cut because a sharp blade going ~200 mph is hitting it. Much like if you swung a sword at it. Think about a weed whacker... similar operation, but no blades to generate the lifting effect you think it needed to cut the grass.. or a sickle, scythe, thing...

Now, I will concede that the lifting effect of the airflow may help in pulling grass up to be cut, but that is more to ensure all the grass is cut evenly vs a part of the cutting process.

The blade does create 'lift' (read airflow) but it's not required to cut the grass, or else line trimmers wouldn't work. The grass breaks when the blade speed is high enough that the grass can't get out of its way (inertia).  The bent blade is a fan that lifts & blows the cut grass into the catcher or out a chute. That effect stops when the bent bit wears out.

There's more to see with lawn mower blades! For instance I bought a battery powered push lawn mower shortly after buying my first home, and there is so much I learned when researching what was best for my situation. One of the things you brought up in this video - the size of the wing on the blade for the amount of lift, and the amount of energy it takes to spin the blade with the greater lift. For instance my battery powered (EGO is the brand) mower has a pretty small wing to get better battery life, but has the tradeoff of not being able to bag as well as some other blades. Some people put different blades on the mower to bag better because they don't need the battery life as much. I think there is a lot to see in trading out blades and seeing the effect it has on the cut, lift, and blow distance/bagging ability.

It's important to remember that grass stands on it's own and springs back to an upright position naturally. By the same token, it seems that the cutting process is very likely a combination of inertial cutting (just hitting it really fast) and pulling the grass taught and cutting.

I don't know if you guys have this in US, but here we use a different kind of lawnmower. It doesn't have a metal blade, it uses a nylon "blade" instead. It spins much faster and doesn't need an engine as powerful as the other mowers. That's why it is lighter and more compact. In this case, you don't need vaccum to hold the tip of the grass up, because the blade is spinning so fast that the inertia on the grass is enough to hold it.

That's not necessarily true :). Due to the shape of the edge of the lawnmower blade, the blade acts like a wing and it literally wants to fly under the deck. If you didn't have the "spoiler" there at the back of the blade, the blade would lift in the airflow and then you wouldn't get an even height cut. Rather than any idea of vacuum holding the grass up, I believe it has to do with the inertia of the mass of the grass blades above the cut. That's why mowing works better the higher the grass is (to a certain point) above where you're cutting it.

I'm not sure that airflow is entirely it, I'd say the speed would matter more. The reason I say this is because the rotary mowers I use for farming aren't enclosed, and the blades are quite different than lawnmower blades, being only three or four inches long. It cuts with long grass and short grass too, so the grass itself isn't the reason why it cuts.

If you want to do videos on lawn care tools, perhaps you might find a stump grinder interesting (I own 4).  Most people expect the stump grinding blade to look like a saw blade but (on my grinders) the "teeth" are actually  round disks mounted on a 20" steel wheel.  The wheel weighs about 250 Lbs (think flywheel), and it spins at about 2,000 rpm.  Most people are amazed to see one in action because it's not really what they expected.  If the grinder is cutting properly (with sharp teeth) the stump grinder will produce curved strips of wood about the diameter of your finger and about 8" long.  The strips remind me of an eyebrow.  Let me know if you want to know more.  I'm sure there would be plenty of people in your area who'd be willing to let you video their machines in action.

To the peeps saying the tab doesn't have a great effect in cutting, you're probably right, but keep this in mind.

I think the biggest issue without the tab would be that the blades will likely create a downward force, like any fan or turbine. If that is the case (and I am entirely assuming here I have next to no knowledge of physics) the grass will likely be pushed down. So I wouldn't say it's entirely necessary for the physical cutting but without it, the grass probably won't prop back up to even make contact.

Edit: I see a bunch of people saying that it's also the case with weed whackers, but again, in that case, the string isn't going to push the blades downwards because it simply won't impart enough of a force to push the blades down since it's a string. The blades of conventional mowers on the other hand are likely to create that pressure.

Grass cutting...I did it for a dozen years or so working in golf course turfgrass maintenance as a worker and as a superintendent of maintenance in NYS and Florida. I loved the quality and precision of cylindrical reel mowers and I thought that when I used a rotary mower, it was a straight up brutal assault on the grass community (or whatever else I was trying to cut). I thought that the key to a better cut was sharpness, not suction but yeah, those tabs at the end of the rotary mower blade did suck and more importantly did shove the grass out of the chute which I always thought was the intended purpose because clogged and wet grass clipping on the inside of a mower housing sucks even more than the wingtips of those blades.

of course, this is an attempt at understanding the mechanical properties of a rotary mower so there is that but here is what is important for me about lawn mowing...ah, it's the smell and the look so I am wondering if an exploration of why fresh cut grass looks and smells so great could be made. There are neurological reasons for why that is but I'm just an experiential philosopher at heart.

Reel mowers (old-fashioned non-powered push mowers and the tractor-pulled mowers used for large fields) use a more scissors-like action. They provide a cleaner cut, but can't handle excessively tall grass. They also don't extract grass well since there's little airflow, so they're best for mulching.
A weed eater also uses something dull (a wire) that is spinning very fast to cut grass and other weeds, but it doesn't use suction. What's the deal?

I think there are multiple variables unaccounted for in your test: grass variety (seems to me coarse grass such as Bermuda cut much differently than fescue), hydrostatic pressure within the individual blades of grass, velocity of the mower blade as it contacts the grass blade (why do old reel mowers work?), angle of the sharpened edge of the mower blade, centripetal forces expelling the cut grass, etc. I agree with others who have asked about old-school flat blades. As I look closer at the high-speed video, I see grass blades that get struck by the mower blade, lie flat for a moment, recoil upright and get struck again. Repeat until the blade of grass gets severed. I don't buy it that there is some sucking power (lift) that draws the blades of grass up and holds them upright to get whacked off by the high speed mower blade. I think the bent blades were designed to provide loft (basically turbulence) of the severed grass particles to increase discharge from the mower deck. If airflow was the main purpose, why are not mower blades shaped more like an airplane propeller with a sharpened leading edge? What about removing the deck altogether and see what the mower blade/grass interaction changes. I think you need to test your hypothesis more.

Something that's important to get right for backyard composting is to keep your carbon (browns):nitrogen (greens) ratio at a good balance. I've been thinking about grass in this context. Fresh grass clippings are considered greens/nitrogen source. If you let the clippings dry out, they become browns/carbon source. In my thinking, the only thing that left the clippings was water, which has neither carbon nor nitrogen, so it shouldn't change the C:N ratio of the grass, and yet. Two things:
1) I want to see a control test here. Take another blade and remove/bend down the tab so there's no more lift. I want to see how that affects it. Personally I suspect that the lift is not what makes it cut, I feel like it's just speed and the inertia of the grass keeps it straight.

Destin, I'd love for you to look at how the Gator style mulching blades change the cutting effect. The lift tab is cut into three sections that are then twisted on an angle. With a conventional hi-lift blade, you'll get clumping of grass pretty easily with tall thick grass. With a gator mulching blade, it's significantly less likely to clump and you can mow much taller grass much easier.

Also, as others have said, the dull blade results in am impact tear, whereas a sharp blade gives a smooth cut. That's why you can look at blades of grass in someone's yard and tell if their mower is sharp or not.

Remember the old trick where you unfold a newspaper and lay it across half a ruler. If you hit the ruler fast enough you could break the ruler in half. Enjoy your stuff. One thing to remember, however, is to not allow your measurement method to impact your results. I think opening the discharge has the same effect as cutting out the front of the mower - it disrupts the air flow and thus the "normal" grass/airflow interaction. I suggest cutting a large hole in your mower deck and forming a clear plastic widow in the shape of the portion you cut out. Install the plastic window in the cutout hole and then filming. In this way the air flow will be minimally disturbed from normal and you will be able to see what really happens. Filming needs to be done as the mower moves forward an normal speed.
I suspect you will find that there is a very high "vertical" air flow in the area between the deck and the blade tip that "lifts/sucks" the grass up to be cut by the next blade as the mower moves forward. I also suspect that if there was a coanda shaped edge on the mower deck and a toroidal space inside but beyond the blade radius you could suck much more air in at the near the blade end. This space would also the radial air flow a place to go. I could explain this better if I could send you a drawing.

I think you only got half the picture here.  Think about what your cutting.  The grass has a huge surface area for what it weighs.  In addition, the grass is really flexible.    The tab sets up a toroidal flow of air inside which initially stands up the blade.  Then, when the mower blade impacts the blade of grass you have a torque moment generated between the blade and the drag from the air moving perpendicular to the blade.  This torque, plus the drag creates a tension in the grass blade which is focused at the point of impact.  Thus the point of impact is the logical failure point.

On the flat blade mowers the wings do provide lift but the important thing is the 45 degree bevel on the blade, it's a one sided cut not like a knife V type sharpening. Because one side is flat (the bottom) and the top is at a 45 it cuts the grass pulling it up at the same time it cuts it. If you sharpen the blade like a knife (V type ) the blade will push the grass down as well as up giving you a uneven cut. Not uncommon for manufactures to recommend setting the deck so the blades are pitched back. The difference in deck and blade height (front to rear) assist bringing the majority of the air flow in the front where the grass is the longest giving the deck the best possibility of standing the grass up so the first cut is efficient. Then as the deck moves forward the back side of the blade deals with shorter more uniform grass height allowing it achieve a more uniform final cut.

That blade is actually called a "High-Lift Blade". A mulching blade is even cooler, it creates a toroid airflow to cut the clippings over and over.

Edit>> You might also be interested to know that on a high-lift or standard-lift blade, only the leading edge usually does the cutting (if you push at the right speed). It actually works by friction, not lift, so you don't want the blade to be too sharp. The lift is for ejecting the clippings. On a mulching blade, there is an extra cutting edge, and the grass is cut the normal way on the leading edge, then again as it is pulled down by the next edge.

Now that we know why and how the grass is cut, we need to focus upon what length we should actually cut our lawn.  Most lower their mower deck too low, which causes the grass root to be either cut or exposed . This results in the root being damaged or exposed to sun etc which results in a brown lawn .  Raise your mower deck one or two notches and you'll see a better looking lawn.  If aesthetics is not important, then leave it at current level.  Another important thing is to keep your mower blade sharp so the grass it's actually being cut and not just hacked . This makes for a nicely cut blade of grass that not only looks better but is healthier.

Okay. I have a huge dilemma. I think the problem lies with the composition of the dirt where I live. I live in Chugwater, Wyoming. The soil comp is mostly very powdery. It has the strangest properties. For example, even after a huge moisture event within a very short period (hours) you can walk on the property and when you go into the house there is hardly any evidence of going outside. Then, in the days where the soil has really dried up and I have to mow I really am just reorganizing the dirt (which we call chalk-rock).
Now. Here is my dilemma. I am running an 18 horse Kubota KX1850 with a 48 inch deck. The blades are considered very high lift. The mower deck has pathways in the construct for efficient airflow for maximum cut results. Well. That is okay as long as you are cutting grass. But the terrain has about 60% dirt and 40% bio-mass material (grass, dandelions, native sweet clover, weeds), basically prarie. When I take the mower-deck off the mower cavity is TOTALLY plugged with a nearly concrete hard collection of the dirt that has been lifted and impacted on the underside of the deck. I can spend as much as 2 hours with an oscillating tool removing the horrible media. The first time I did it I used an air-chisel! I find the oscillating tool less harmful to the metal of the mower-deck.
I have a theory. The dirt is such fine material and the ultra-high lift property of the blades blasts the underside of the mower-deck. In fact I think the blades, when spinning at full-throttle, atomizes the dirt even more and 'paints' the metal (a rough surface really) and then builds thickness. It is so bad that it grinds the tips of the blades as the collection of dirt builds to the point that it interferes with the path of the blades (3x @ $56/pop). I have to replace the blades at least 2 times each summer (after 3 mowings).
I am the only person with this problem in our town. But I am the only one with this large a mower and with the proprietary Kubota blades (I experimented with some mulching blades--lower lifting properties) but then the lift was missing and the blades did not cut efficiently because when you use mulching blades you also need to choke off the discharge chute.
I have discovered some things that help.
1) After a good mower-deck cleaning make sure the first area mowed is the part of the 'lawn' that has a lot of grass. I do have 2 areas where the grass to dirt ratio is about 80/20. That puts a layer of somewhat moist media on the underside of the deck. Mow this prior to hitting the very dusty areas. By doing this there is at least a 'buffer zone' of grassy accumulation between the deck and the dust.
2) Reduce the RPM when possible. The blades will still function properly as they are ultra-high-lift blades. By lowering the RPM in extremely dusty areas less dust/dirt will be impacted on the metal surface.

The problem is so bad that I have even worn a filtered mask with charcoal filters. From a block away it looks like a cloud of smoke coming from the parsonage lawn!! No one believes me when I tell them the difficulty of removing the 'concrete' from the underside of the mower-deck until they see it for themselves.

Help!!

I look forward to comments and suggestions.

I'm not sure you've got it right about how the lawnmower works. That tab is most likely there for two reasons. 1) it creates a down push on the blade so that it doesn't bend and rise while rotating fast and 2) it should stiffen the blade against the bending as well.
A sheet of paper doesn't hurt at slow speed, but a fast draw can cut things, even with a sheet of paper. Think about a card from a deck of cards. At the right speed those can penetrate into cork board. Well, you've got metal whipping along at 200mph, which is probably fast enough that the blades of grass can't bend out of the way faster than the blade of the mower passes through them. And since the grass naturally wants to stand up, it gets torn or cut at about the height of the blade. Those blades are passing over each area about 45 times a second, so even if it doens't get a good cut on the first pass, it will on the next 45+ passes.
The airflow is more likely used to get rid of the detritus, not make the blades stand up.

Lift and drag are not proportional, they are quadratic :D
Cx=Cx0 + (Cz^2)\(pi*lambda*fq)

Where lambda is the ratio of the wingspan divided by the surface.
And fq is the "facteur de qualité" (ie quality factor) wich describe the ability of your wing to minimize the vortex created at your wingtip :)

-A French Engineering Student at ISAE-ENSMA

Destin, may I respectfully disagree with your conclusions?  The bar itself is the wing, since even a sheet of plywood flowing through air or water has aero/hydro-dynamic properties. This is functioning like a symmetric wing, which doesn't produce any lift force at 0 degrees angle of attack. The "lift tab", if it gives the wing tip any camber at all would mean a negative angle of attack of the resultant chord, and the tab would actually be creating the high pressure zone above the bar, and the lower pressure under, resulting in a downforce on the blade tip. The tab is acting more like a "vortex generator" on a fixed airplane wing, with the turbulent vortex created in the wake of the blade providing the updraft that's straightening the grass. Only the tip of the bar is sharpened and it's this part of the blade, rotating into the vortex created by the opposite side's rotation, that's cutting the grass.

I think that the lifting due to the airflow is negligible for the cutting. It is likely useful to push the cut grass out of the way and collecting it, but I believe that you would get the same cut even with a flat blade. I'm not entirely convinced that the upward force from the lawnmower blade plays an especially significant role in the cutting part of mowing. Certainly it's useful overall, since it's what lets the lawnmower collect the grass in a bag or in the case of mulching mowers, suck it up so it gets hit by the blades again and again until it's shredded into little pieces. However, an object moving at 200 MPH will rip or cut through grass regardless of airflow. There's just too much friction against the edge of the blade and inertia making the grass fold over onto the blade as it moves past for there to be any chance of it somehow whipping back around and sliding under the blade intact.

I'd like to see a control test with the curved lifting portions cut off to give a flat blade. Also, what if you installed the blade upside down so that it provided down force? A comparison of the quality of the lawn cut under these conditions would be very interesting! This would test the assumption that the lifting blade pulls flattened blades back up straight again so they're cut to the same length as all the others. If this is the case, doing a comparison immediately after mowing might be a mistake since any blades that were flattened by the mower may still be laying flat. Better to give it 24 hours after mowing for the wind to straighten them up again first.

As far as I can tell, the lifting lawn mower blade is a relatively new invention. Before this, blades were presumably flat, though sadly I can't find pictures of old lawn mower blades anywhere on Google. Apparently there are no antique lawn mower blade collectors for some reason.
